Title: "Host"
Pros: Fun environment, great people, learned a lot. I learned a lot of customer service. it will teach you how to handle a crowded environment and how handle being overwhelmed
Cons: travel, money, bad management. time and setup is a drag.
Advice to Management: trust your employee more

Title: "assistant manager"
Pros: great pay, obtainable bonus, 5 day work week
Cons: very political, different "rules" for different people
Advice to Management: more consistancy

Title: "key"
Pros: -atmosphere -co-workers -meal discounts -wage -able to move up in the company
Cons: -organization -accountability -equipment maintenance -peak sales hours
Advice to Management: Employees need to be held accountable for their mistakes. Proper steps need to be taken to help reduce these occurrences.

Title: "Manager (service/kitchen)"
Pros: Was fantastic when I first started but they had a huge management change and it went downhill after that
Cons: They are open till 2 a.m. you will work for more hours than they claim in the beginning. Don't expect to have a home life. You are at the mercy of your general manager you could end up doing the majority of the work. They asked the district manager who had been in his position for 11 years and with the company for nearly 30 years to either step down or be fired. Very sad. Very disrespectful treatment of a great man and mentor.
Advice to Management: I would say try to emulate the top companies to work for. Find out what's going on a microscale in your restaurant instead of having your district manager speak super technically and above the problem. Start getting down in the trenches and find out what's really going on. Don't keep general managers around that refused to hire extra staff when they have plenty of applications. Not having enough staff means the guest experience goes to the pits and your reputation is ruined. Try to run things in a way that makes your employees and managers think you respect their work, instead of running it like its only for profit. There is a lot of talk about taking care of people and how your numbers will follow but it is not what I have seen in person. This is why I believe the Austin area is so low on managers people are jumping off this ship at a high rate. I think you should not immediately take the guests words when they complain to corporate. I have seen many times when people lie to try to get extra money or extra things for free. It seems like if the customer has a bad reputation in a town for behaving badly you wouldn't give them precedence. If several people are telling you the same thing you may consider it. We have allowed the customers to badger and mistreat the servers and staff. This needs to stop. Overall don't recommend working for this company at all right now.

Title: "Applebee's"
Pros: The atmosphere is nice, there are nice people there, and the managers are nice.
Cons: Cleaning the bathrooms, and cleaning up after children
Advice to Management: Be more understanding

Title: "Extra long hours, no life."
Pros: They have a great training program. You really learn a lot.
Cons: You are at work most of the time, get to go home really late 4 or 5am sometimes. No time for social life.
Advice to Management: Stop taking perks away from employees.

Title: "It was fun being there. We really were like a huge family!"
Pros: We were like a family. The managers there would help anyone out with anything in the restaurant if it needed to be done. We all had each other's backs.
Cons: I reached my highest available pay raise not to far into my employment. And it was not a lot.
Advice to Management: The managers at Applebee's are probably the greatest I've seen yet! My advice to CORPORATE is that maybe if you didn't pay your employees badly, you'd keep some of the good ones.

Title: "Waiter"
Pros: Flexible schedules. Awesome people to work with and you get to meet a lot of cool customers.
Cons: Working for tip can be kind of tedious. Some people just refuse not to tip. And management can be rather wacky. There are usually 3 or 4 different managers on at a time and they don't coordinate well.

Title: "Job was Soaking me dry at $4.00 the hour and measley tipouts"
Pros: I plead the 5th!! There are no pros here
Cons: Everything was wrong with management, except for the GM and the kitchen manager
Advice to Management: STOP THE FAVORITISM!!! And the managers need to stop using the cute waitresses as their little sex kittens!

Title: "Great College Job"
Pros:
Worked around my schedule in order for me to still be able to attend my classes.
Management was very nice
Cons:
Very stressful at times.
Requires you to be on your feet for long bouts of time.
Hard to get people to cover your shifts
Advice to Management: Listen to your staff

Title: "General Manager"
Pros: Lots of resources to learn and improve your performance. Well respected franchise.
Cons: Being a "lower volume" restaurant means that as a GM I am a dishwasher, cook, bartender, expo, prep cook and janitor. Our market is saturated and it is extremely difficult to retain good employees.
Advice to Management: Listen to your employees and managers- ask our opinions on things. Get rid of the GEM system and ABA's- managers are behind a clip board and a computer more then they are worried about good food, satisfied guests and happy employees.

Title: "Kitchen manager"
Pros: AppleSauce franchise treats it's managers well. Bonus program is worthwhile and attainable.
Cons: Long hours. Work/family balance is tough but where is it not in hospitality management?
Advice to Management: Stay classy

Title: "Review"
Pros: It's good pay depending on which area you get hired. You're pretty much guaranteed to get around 30 hours a week.
Cons: If you get hired with full availability you're never allowed to change that. I got hired with full availability and now i work every single weekend while attending college. Also you don't get over time if you reach 40 hours a week. And it's pretty much impossible to call off work because you're responsible for getting somebody to cover your shift.
Advice to Management: Let employees call off work when they need to.

Title: "Great for Experience"
Pros:
Great co-workers and managers.
Will hire first-time servers.
Decent hours.
Busy in the winter.
Cons:
Will not let you call in sick unless you are on your deathbed.
Hard to move up.
Biased towards certain employees.
 Not very good tips (lots of teens and cheap menu items)
Advice to Management: Listen to your employees and treat them all equally, do not cater to a select few.

Title: "Slaving"
Pros: You get free meals sometimes
Cons: They don't pay you much

Title: "The good with the bad."
Pros: Managers made sure the place was cleaned before letting you leave. (I liked this because that means when I came in, it was clean too.) When I compare this place to others, this is one of my top jobs that I could take pride in because our back of house was clean and our food was good. We passed health inspections with an A, easy.
Cons: There was a lot of work expected, and high volume of business with low pay. They expected you to work varying shifts that changed within a week. It made it hard if you had classes, kids, or another job to work around.
Advice to Management: Show that you value your employees more with better pay. A semi set (or at least sometimes set) schedule should be easier to come by.

Title: "work hard, play hard"
Pros: great coworkers, (personally) had good managers, fast promotions for hard work.
Cons: A lot of turn over, hard to get shifts covered

Title: "Great Experience"
Pros: Friendly Co-Workers, who worked as a team and got the job done. Everyone held accountable for work or was held accountable by peers/management.
Cons: Serving is feast of famine. When busy, tips are great! When slow, not so much! Location is a huge factor, too. Stores in better areas of town had better patrons, whereas seedy areas were obviously a reflection of guests at store.
Advice to Management: Keep up the good work and continue to promote from within! :)

Title: "Don't go corporate."
Pros: Great tips, easy menu, family atmosphere.
Cons: Corporate is horrible, too many rules, menus changes too much, never have the supplies we need, understaffed.
Advice to Management: Hire the right amount of staff we need, give shifts based of performance, make sure to order supplies.

Title: "Waiter"
Pros: good money, made nice friends, management is respectful.
Cons: Working with the public is hard, late nights, and weekends. No holidays off,
Advice to Management: Health Benefits

Title: "Meoshia"
Pros: The people was nice it was a wonderful environment and experience for me.
Cons: Not the workers but some times it was the customers,some was just having a bad day and would take it out on you and no matter what you had to have a smile on your face.

Title: "Fun job"
Pros: This was a fun job, easy, mindless work. If as a host you got in good with the servers, you could make $50-$100 in tips in one night.
Cons: Management was difficult. HIGH turnover.

Title: "Pays the Bills"
Pros: Upbeat work environment, several sales incentives, opportunities for promotion
Cons: No breaks during an eight hour work shift, no uniform compensation, termination dependent upon customer satisfaction
Advice to Management: Use employee input to provide a better overall environment for employees and guests

Title: "Server to Management"
Pros: Good corporate salary. Thorough training
Cons: Typically below average clientele. Chain food quality.

Title: "Human Resources"
Pros: I love the environment I work in!
Cons: Cubicles are terrible to work in.
Advice to Management: More offices not cublicles

Title: "Applebees"
Pros: discounts on food and drinks was nice and as you progress through the chain you earn the ability to give friends and family discounts too
Cons: long hours, hard and physically demanding work. not always the best clientele but that is not the restaurants fault.

Title: "Kitchen manger"
Pros: Decent pay, black and white policies, predictable business, bonus program
Cons: Work for the wrong franchise group and life can be hell with little to no bonus and tons of hours
Advice to Management: Offer 401k, restructure bonus program, reward your stronger employees

Title: "Assistant Manager"
Pros: Great Employees and Good Pay
Cons: Long hours for management (55+ a week) not idea if you have a family
Advice to Management: Be consistent

Title: "Better than most "corporate restaurant" jobs"
Pros: Some of the pros of this job were excellent coworkers, good management, flexible hours and scheduling, everyone was very efficient and eager to let you know when you're doing a good job, and a relaxed atmosphere.
Cons: Some of the cons of working here were too many servers on in one shift, small (number of tables) sections, cheap prices which lead to cheap check averages and smaller tips, and the integrity of about 40% of customers served would be questioned by most.
Advice to Management: I would advise the management to remember that yes you are working for a big boss and yes you do have to follow the rules and standards of the company but if your employees are not making enough money to live or are capable of taking on more responsibility than what they're being given an in return suffering financially from it then you as the management team of your crew should try to find a solution so that your employees are getting the hours that they need to survive.

Title: "Nice Team - Pushy on Upselling for Add-Ons"
Pros: Nice team. Overall, the managers will work with you.
Cons: Up-selling, your performance reviews based on up-sells. They expect you to sell alcohol even in the first shift. Never mind that you are on time every day and never call in sick, managers review employees based on up-sells. Also, the managers expect employees to push surveys so that they can get their bonuses.

Title: "I love the people!"
Pros: Some of the greatest people you will ever work with, 50% discount on food, get to meet new people every day.
Cons: You cannot ever get the smell of applebees out of the clothes you wear to work. I literally burnt mine. Also, the corporate rules when the big cheeses come in are stupid. Also, if you host and you are good at your job.... dont expect any of your other fellow hosts to help. Its easy to overload yourself. I also had to clean up puke from people of all ages.
Advice to Management: Get to know the people you have employed, it will really help in the long run.

Title: "Great except the Cliques"
Pros: Most of the employees were friendly. Management was great. Received food disounts when working.
Cons: Cliques of people will turn on you if your comments hurt another one of the clique members, even if unintentional.
Advice to Management: figure out a new tipping system for servers tipping out host's etc., that way you can track who is being fair to host's and who isn't. when you go 2 months without getting tippied from the same servers you start to hold a grudge against them

Title: "Server"

Cons: good pay is not a guarantee. rules are not enforced as they should be, and some employees are not held to the standard that they should be.

Title: "General Manager"

Title: "Good staff"

lots of work for low low pay

working on tips is horrible for this job. no one ever tips i walked away with maybe 30$ a night if that..

Title: "Great 1st job"

Title: "Not worth the time"

Cons: The work environment itself was very negative and filled with drama the servers who had been working there the longest got the best sections which meant that if you were newly hired you were put in terrible sections with low support, and were unlikely to make any money by the end of the evening. Also having to tip out to food staff or bartenders when they made more than me.
Advice to Management: Give more support or opportunities to work for servers who are struggling in their sections.

Title: "Server"

Good first job
Make lots of friends
Easy-going atmosphere
Flexible schedule
Cons:
Tips are usually low
Most of the business is in the bar
Rude customers
Open till 2

Try to actually listen to your employees
Don't pick favorites

Title: "Server"
Pros: Can be fun environment with some friendly coworkers
Cons: Can be stressful with unfriendly coworkers
Advice to Management: Stop changing management so much. My head was spinning with management changes!

Title: "WOW"
Pros: There is literally nothing good about working at this place. The money is good but the environment is the worst thing i have encountered in my entire work life.
Cons: Refer back to the pros section above. Lol this place has too many cons and is not worth the time of typing them.
Advice to Management: Go back to college and find a different career field because you messed up and chose the wrong one.

Title: "Neighborhood Expert"
Pros: Applebee's gave me pocket cash when I was working my way through school.
Cons: The restaurant is totally corrupt. The manager to everything to appease the bigger bosses and it makes everyone miserable.
Advice to Management: You'll get a lot more out of your employees if you treat them better.

Title: "what the?"
Pros: Staff is nice for the most part. Food is good. Hiring process was easy, and standard with background check and drug test.
Cons: The TGM at the store I was training in was the absolute fakest person I have ever met. Also a pervert. If you want a server or host job in his store and you are female, you better know someone or be young and pretty. There is no "training" for managers. You get out to work and do somebody else's job so they can be sent home to save on labor. It's a complete joke. The most unprofessional training program I've ever been involved in. Also the pay sounds great until you avg it out to the 55-60hrs a week and subtract the expensive insurance plan.
Advice to Management: Stop being lazy and train the correct way. Having someone training doesn't mean they are they're to do your job. They are suppose to learn from you. When it comes time labor is high putting a trainee into the middle of a firestorm is not the best way to train.

Title: "Fun but work"

Title: "Mediocre restaurant, Worse Employment"
Pros: They have locations everywhere so transferring or moving and getting a job is doable.
Cons: Unwilling to pay for standards they set. They constantly cut hours and positions and expect everyone else to pick up the slack for the same pay. For example, while employed I witnessed management remove the expo, dishwashers, and prep. They expect the cooks to prep, wash dishes, stock, count inventory, unload trucks, and reduce ticket times in-between orders. The equipment is old, dirty, and constantly malfunctioning. They constantly change their products and add menu items to the point that even management has troubling remembering ingredients. The pos systems are running windows 2000 and constantly go down. They require that new employees go through two weeks of training. However, they are unwilling to pay an employee to do the training so the processes ends being a new employee on their own station while current employees from the other stations bark out instructions to them. If you fall behind and your ticket times go over the magical number they set, management will harass you from the other side of the line. They do not offer vacation, insurance, personal days, or benefits of any kind. You will have to work holidays, including Thanksgiving and Christmas eve. They do not allow gratuity or compensation for table complaints or unpaid checks. Employees are expected to show up regardless of weather conditions and are expected to stay open without considering the safety of their employees. Health codes prevent sick people from handling food but if you have a cold and call out they expect you to bring a note from a doctor. Did I mention they do not offer health insurance? Upper management set goals that are mathematically unreachable and expect store employees to explain why the store is down in sales. For example, they charge over three dollars for their soft drinks and when customers get water, they blame the servers for not up-selling beverages.They are terribly understaffed and have a very high turnover.
Advice to Management: As a cookie cutter restaurant, you can differentiate your products in ways other than offering 85 mediocre menu items that slightly differ from the 85 menu items offered by the other cookie cutters restaurants. Cut your menu, stop modifying recipes based on slight differences in ingredients, and be realistic with the ridiculous standards you set. Pick a path, cut labor and positions and save money, or pay the labor to get those things done. It's like you want to have your cake, eat it too, and also not pay for it.

Advice to Management: Stop caring so much about yourself, and pay more attention to your employees, There's a reason why almost all restaurants have a 300% turnover rate.

Title: "it is rewarding although it can be hard at times."
Pros: The tips can be pretty generous which is always a plus and you can meet some really good people on the job.
Cons: There is no con as it is a job you have to know how to deal with everything it is a very reliable job at the end of the day.
Advice to Management: The management is doing good and they do not need to change anything i my book overall they are good all around.

Title: "Chaotic mess."
Pros:
This is a difficult review to write because I initially worked at an Applebee's that cared about employee performance, employee happiness, and guest's experience. However, I transferred to another Applebee's and the managers are careless and want to squeeze by on guest's happiness and especially on employee's happiness. So for pros:

Family oriented.
Laid back atmosphere.
Simple menu.
Cons:
Depending on your scheduled time you could possibly work until 2am or later.
Chaotic kitchen.
Low check averages.
Large amounts of messed up food (however this is based on the efforts of the cooks).
Management can be careless.

Title: "Working at an Applebee's really all depends on your manager. Wasn't terrible, wasn't great."
Pros: You become a family with the other employees.
Cons: Managers don't always seem to know what they're doing.

Title: "Applebee's was a wonderful entry level service job>"
Pros: Can learn a lot about how to make money through hospitality
Cons: Low menu prices= Low tip percentages
Advice to Management: Managers are awesome concept is becomes out grown

Title: "This was the best experience of my life."
Pros: Great pay and great people to work with in all levels of the organization.
Cons: Can't remember the last time I worked a 55 hour work week. You have to put in 65 plus to survive and be suceesful.
Advice to Management: Remember you are only as strong as your weakest link. But why is that link weak. See above quality of life.

Title: "Great Management!!!"
Pros:
-Flexible scheduling
-Positive team environment
-Good mix of employees
Cons:
-Training seemed tedious if you have already been a server
-Some requests off were ignored even after being accepted on Stafflinq
Advice to Management: -Communication between managers was almost non-existent, get on the same page!

Title: "12 years with the company"
Pros: Write your own schedule, high bonus potential
Cons: Nights and weekends, low base salary

Title: "Fun place to work"
Pros: Good tips, fun co workers, good atmosphere
Cons: Management trends to favor men
Advice to Management: Reward all employees, but just the men

Title: "Server"
Pros: Co workers are amazing, customers are okay
Cons:
*Childlike management
*Lies, manipulations, favoritism, and downright despicable ways they treat employees
Advice to Management: Hire adults that haven't slept with half of their staff.

Title: "Theres alot of drama involed"
Pros: The coworkers, promotions, tips, understanding of schedule
Cons: Management, working late late hours, often no tips, tip share with other hosts
Advice to Management: Learn how to listen

Title: "New faces all the time no matter what. at least the management and food are pretty consistent"
Pros: quick money with unlimited potential depending on how efficient you are
Cons: the intensity of the restaurant can be daunting
Advice to Management: slow down. everything around you is warp speed

Title: "I was a server running around, tending to the needs of the person to my right, left, front, and back."
Pros: It teaches you how to organize your time, and multi-task. I have never worked in an environment where every second mattered, and mult-tasking to such a degree was essential.
Cons: The compensation in general as a server is low.
Advice to Management: Inform the servers of upcoming changes to the menu before you walk out on the floor to find out by having a customer ask you about the new change.

Title: "Bad management"
Pros: Food is great employees are amazing and location is great
Cons: Management doesn't think about the reason we go do this job everyday the GUEST!!!! NOT CUSTOMER!!!!
Advice to Management: GET YOUR HEAD OUY OF YOUR *** AND REMEMBER WHY YOU TOOK THIS JOB!!!!!!

Title: "Working for applebees was my first real job"
Pros: its a job atleast there will always be issues waitressing. its not a career but its a way to make money
Cons: dont really have Any cons i had a somewhat pleasant experience. ITS NOT A CAREER

Title: "Server"
Pros: None at all. Poor food and worse management.
Cons: Racist and clannish. Dirty and would never allow any friend of family member eat there.
Advice to Management: Leave and let good people run the business

Title: "Very enjoyable exciting fun"
Pros: Meet new people working with the public got to do what i loved
Cons: didn't really have any dislike

Title: "It was like working at a day care, but the day care is for the employees and managers."
Pros: Got to work with my high school friends and we always helped each other as a team.
Cons: Horrible with setting up hours. Management did not know how to handle their employees nor the customers in a professional matter. Restaurant was never taken care of properly by the team.
Advice to Management: As a former employee, you need to find people that are actually considered for the job instead of hiring anything that wants a job.

Title: "Fast-paced but fun"
Pros: Great co-workers, (mostly) friendly customers, fast-paced so time went by fast
Cons: Some rude Customers, late nights,
Advice to Management: Listen more to employees

Title: "Fun place to work while in school."
Pros: Fun people, decent tips, friendly customers, good food, half off meal at the end of the day
Cons: Terrible managing, staying until 2 in the morning, no benefits, schedule you even when you need off for school(might just be the location)
Advice to Management: Hire managers that have management experience to avoid a power trip.

Title: "Worked there for 1 year."
Pros: It was busy. Time flew by and they closed the kitchen before the bar so we got out earlier than the wait staff.
Cons: Worked 7 days a week most weeks. The shifts were really short and I worked a lot of doubles. Spent 70 hours tied to work while only working 45 hours.
Advice to Management: Better training of staff starting with the managers. They were just glorified line cooks with no real kitchen knowledge or advice.

Title: "Bulk food purchasing agent"
Pros: Nice pay for the restaurant industry
Cons: Little advancement opportunities within the purchasing career track
Advice to Management: More base pay; less bonus

Title: "Friendly staff, management OK."
Pros: The crew are awesome, pretty flexible with shifts. The work is pretty simple, be friendly and work quickly.
Cons: Don't approve of how the area GMs try to 'inspire' you to work harder. During my first few days of training we got severely yelled at and it just didn't seem the right way to talk to your employees/

Title: "Not what I had expected at all"
Pros: The atmosphere of the other staff was a family oriented environment. I loved the waitresses that I worked with.
Cons: I work with very nice people until I found out u had a rare illness that prohibited me from standing on my leg too long. When it came time to quit that's when they treated me as if I did something wrong and basically was told to never go back to that resturant again.
Advice to Management: Be more understanding of people's circumstances

Title: "Good Job"
Pros: The people that are there make the job even better. You can work 25 hours a weeks and still make a pretty decent amount.
Cons: The hours there are sometimes long and when you are actually there for a while and they value your work nights are very late and long.
Advice to Management: Sometimes they really don't care, they are very flexible.

Title: "Descent while in college"
Pros: Flexible hours, typically descent co-workers, low pressure
Cons: late nights, High school drama

Title: "Decent pay but not enough to cover all the work you do"
Pros:
Pay was around $8.50 an hour after taxes
Rarely lag time
Free soda
50% discount on food within a half hour of your shift, 30% discount eating out with a party of 5 or less (15% party of 6+)
Cons:
Hours are not set (you go home when they tell you to)
You're really doing three jobs in one (bussing, hosting, and serving food) but only get paid for one job
Work is exhausting
Coworkers were very catty and would talk about each other behind everyone's backs
Servers are supposed to clear everything but cups from tables but hosts end up clearing the entire table.
No breaks even when you should get one
Advice to Management: Pay hosts more since they do more work than the servers and make way less. There is a reason why the position has such a high turnover rate.

Title: "Manager"
Pros: Can eat whatever I want all day if I want
Cons: Don't make staff learn the menu
Advice to Management: Revolt

Title: "Frustrating."
Pros: For the most part, friendly people and I never get tired of the food.
Cons: I did well as a host and was told that in 2 months at my first job I would be moved up to serving full time. It took 3 months for them to fit in 5 training shifts, all the while hiring and training 7 new servers. I now host 5 days a week in the mornings, where I make no money at all, and I'm supposed to serve once a week. They've told me I have to bring in someone who will be able to host in the mornings before I can start serving more. I don't understand how it's my fault that no morning hosts are being hired. I'm constantly doing extra work and not being thanked for it. There's nothing I'd rather do than quit right now.
Advice to Management: Get your act together.

Title: "Do not apply."
Pros: The benefits were okay but I would not recommend working at this company.
Cons: management is disrespectful, no breaks, minimum wage pay, did not care about workers
Advice to Management: Fair wages, Guarantee breaks, Better Leadership

Title: "Not a generous corporation!"
Pros: The people I work with are easy to get along with.
Cons:
-Management is often unfriendly and disrespectful.
-Corporate gives employees only half off price on their food and they do the same thing with their customers for every night.
-Corporate shows no appreciation in their employee's hard word and loyalty.
-Management is very lazy and has host and servers do tasks that aren't relevant to their job discribtion.
Advice to Management:
- Get active not slouch around
- Show respect to employees that work hard for you
- Share info to all employee by word of mouth not just by posting forms on the walls in the back of the restrauntant.

Title: "Company is a decent first job, but not recommended long term. Very little pay and a lot of work involved."
Pros: Static environment. You know what to expect going to work everyday. Management tries to be as fair as possible when delegating tasks.
Cons: Skewed morals. Made you offer alcohol to minors as one of their 5 points of service, and then refuse them the alcohol when their ID proved their age.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Tips are moderate to average
Cons: Salary very extremely unbelievably low
Advice to Management: Appreciate your good employees

Title: "Had it's ups & downs.. mainly downs."
Pros: Decent money. Lenient dress code. Get to take home all your money at the end of the night.
Cons: Expect very long night shifts and having to stay 2 hours to do sidework. There is a 3.5% tip-out of total sales which goes to hosts and bartenders. So you do lose money if a table stiffs you. If the tip-out is going to the bar, it should be a tip out of drinks, not total sales, IMO. Very rapid turnover of employees, but the managers don't care who they lose. Clientele at this location is horrible. That's probably the worst part.
Advice to Management: Go easy on the favoritism of your workers. And if you have a worker throwing up at work.. you should probably send them home next time.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Flexible scheduling, Positive corporate culture, Teamwork based
Cons: Working for tips is not consistent
Advice to Management: None

Title: "It was a great company to work for with the ability for development. They prefer to promote from within."
Pros: They thrive on employee development. They are extremely passionate with not only their guests but also their employees.
Cons: Once you get into management sometimes the balance is not their between your worklife and your personal life.

Title: "A flexible enough schedule for a college student"
Pros: Flexible schedule, great co-workers, mostly enjoyable guests and there are growth opportunities.
Cons:
The management was very off. Many employees left solely because of the managers.
Changed schedules without much notice. This is important if you have other responsibilities like school.
Way too demanding. Often expect you to do things outside of your job description even when they are aware that it is not part of the job, i.e., having hosts/hostesses cleaning bathrooms. The district manager had to come in and tell us to stop cleaning them.
Advice to Management: Don't try to deceive employees about what their job truly is. I was doing many things outside of my job description that have gotten the management into trouble and they continued to do so.

Title: "Great! Loved the atmosphere"
Pros: The guests, coworkers, and food.
Cons: The slow business days were an issue but other than that nothing really to critique about Applebees or the company.
Advice to Management: Promote from within more often

Title: "This company is flexible in scheduling needs."
Pros: Applebee's offers a flexible work schedule, convenient for students and one looking for supplemental income. It also offer cash pay on a daily basis at the end of each shift.
Cons: In the restaurant there is not very much room for growth and advancement, The program that is in place did not seem to work well for myself or someone else in a lateral position where there should have been room to make a shift into the management training program.
Advice to Management: Work more closely with the shift coordinators to work the advancement program that was suppose to be in place.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Great Co-workers. Fun environment. Good money on some nights.
Cons: Over worked. Management needs to improve. Not much room for growth.

Title: "Undervalued and Belittled"
Pros: I like almost all of the servers I work with, and I can genuinely say that I like the food and products that we sell. I enjoy Applebee's as a restaurant and that hasn't changed since I began working there.
Cons: Management here is completely bent out of shape over following protocol to the letter. Micro-managing to the extreme! For some reason, the shift change between lunch and dinner occurs at 4:00pm, but in many cases we receive a rush of guests at this time and it is nearly impossible for servers and hosts to keep up with who is on the floor and who isn't. I am not sure why this policy exists, but everyone thinks it is ridiculous and damages the experience of the guests. Management here also needs improvement. They do not communicate well with each other, and one of them is verbally abusive toward employees. I (and the other employees) are always talked down to by him as though we are stupid, even though this is far from true. Every week someone is in tears over the way they have been talked to. I am not given enough hours weekly (sometimes only one shift) and yet they keep hiring more hosts. I feel like I do not make enough money here to have to put up with verbal abuse and nonsensical policies. I plan to leave as soon as I have another option.
Advice to Management: Treat your employees like they have brains, let them answer your questions when you ask them, and speak to them like you would like to be spoken to. No one likes having a finger wagged in their face or made to feel like they're being scrutinized at every moment. Communicate with each other so that your employees are not confused because they get two different sets of instructions. It is easier for your employees to respect you if you respect them first.

Title: "Great company"
Pros: Great compensation for the hours worked. The general manager is excellent
Cons: You are on your feet a lot
Advice to Management: Management is what set Applebee's apart. Keep up the good work!

Title: "Don't get sick"
Pros: Great atmosphere, good food, fun employees.
Cons: If you are ill they fire you, even if you can prove you're in the hospital.

Title: "Terrible pay. Managers are unprofessional. 'Favorites' are made. Company overall is cheap."
Pros: potential for good tips during weekends and/or school breaks. The 'chain name' is behind you. Flexible schedules.
Cons: Pay. No tip guarantee. Tip Out is unfair. Bartender gets part of your total sales even if you did not sell a single lick of alcohol. Major glass ceiling. No benefits, compensation OR overtime.
Advice to Management: Stop belittling employees and make the pay fair. Communication with the Corporate Office about waiter's concerns is the only way you are going to keep employees. Also, learning employee's names correctly helps keep them too.

Title: "Applebee's"
Pros: Applebee’s has great menu consistency for repeat guest.
Cons: Applebee’s has long hours but that to be expected in this field.

Title: "Great Company!"
Pros: Great Company to work for
Cons: Company needs to focus more on promotions and salary increases
Advice to Management: Great Job!

Title: "It was okay"
Pros: the best part to working here was because of the flexibilty and working with the people. Trying out new foods and drinks, just the community that was built
Cons: Management was not ideal and could have used some courses in business ethics. Also the area manager was unprofessional with the way he talked to his staff.
Advice to Management: Take business courses and learn how to keep valuable employees wanting to help Your business grow.

Title: "Good starting salarie for non college graduate"
Pros: Applebees is an established restaurant chain , there is a definite sense of job security
Cons: Long hours , late nights

Title: "Mediocre Place to work"
Pros: Good sales and customer service experience, opportunity to make good friends, good way to make decent money fairly quickly
Cons: Hours, rude customers, out of touch management, servers get milked for labor and still get a huge chunk of tips deducted for "tipshare"
Advice to Management: Pay servers minimum wage if you're going to be making them do "sidework" on top of waiting tables. Tips are not compulsory income therefore shouldn't be "tipshared"

Title: "Overall, a positive experience."
Pros:
-good work hours
-friendly coworkers
-potential to move up
Cons:
-a lot of inside drama
-very political
Advice to Management: Stop playing favorites

Title: "this company was ok to work for in the kitchen how ever the hours in the kitchen were not very good"
Pros: the pay was decent for a kitchen position, the people were nice, the job was nice and physically and mentally demanding
Cons: the hours were not good barely worked over 20 hours a week, most of the work force in the kitchen only spoke spanish
Advice to Management: hire more people that speak FLUENT english and offer more hours for the employees 40+

Title: "you deal with a lot, but you still make more than hourly at mcdonalds or somewhere."
Pros: cash in hand when you leave, opportunity for advancement
Cons: the type of people you deal with (always trying to get free meals)
Advice to Management: listen to the employees more, not all guests can be wowed, not all guests are right.

Title: "It's been a very fast paced and almost unbelievably smooth work experience so far."
Pros: Great people, great place to work and above all great food! Employee discount is wonderful.
Cons: It is either very fast paced or very slow.
Advice to Management: Keep up the great work!

Title: "Horrible food and miserable management"
Pros: Tips, and the flexible hours and schedule that comes with a restaurant job.
Cons: The management, the food, the cleanliness, the high school atmosphere, basically everything.

Title: "Terrible"
Pros: If you're lucky to work with cool people.
Cons: Management is lazy unorganized and don't care about the workers. Building is dirty. Anyone and I mean anyone can work here. I worked with a guy who did drugs on the line and another who drink beer by the case on the line. Managers will have you there until the next day working and clock you out hours before you actually leave.
Advice to Management: Resign and let someone who cares take over.

Title: "Out of the pan into the fire"
Pros: The management is interactive with the employee's and they encourage you to help one another using the Applebuddy system. Friendly environment, for the most part, and received help when I needed it using the POS. They also provided 50% off for those that ate there.
Cons: Really lackluster training that should be reinforced by management and current employees. Clientele is what you'd expect and generally management concedes to the customer that just makes enough of a complaint to receive something for free. Black light parties only bolstered alcohol sales and more customers leaving Applebee's under the influence. Servers were always stressed about being sat more than they could handle, but the jobs of the hosts at Applebee's are to seat any spot that is open, and to not go on a wait whatsoever. This really upset the servers because their sections would be packed but they wouldn't have greeted half the tables yet. Silverware needs to be washed twice in the dishwasher rather than once because they were often dirty, along with the plastic cups.
Advice to Management: Create smaller sections with less tables because clearly servers are being overwhelmed during peak rush-hours. The POS computer systems would often crash or experience some difficulty starting up again. Dish pit was overloaded when there wasn't a dishwasher to clean the dishes so ultimately a server would have to do dishes when they already had their own tables.

Title: "Line Cook"
Pros: the managers are tremendous and are always willing to help you with TO and adding picking up shifts when needed
Cons: if you can't stand the heat get out of the kitchen its as simply as that. some people are just not able to keep up
Advice to Management: non

Title: "Server"
Pros: Great work environment. Flexible schedule. Cool coworkers. Can work as much or as little as you want.
Cons: Open on Thanksgiving and Christmas.
Advice to Management: More communication between managers would allow for more consistency.

Title: "Good potential for advancement to the General Manager level, but way too much focus on Overall Satisfaction surveys"
Pros: Good programs, constantly changing food items to keep things fresh
Cons: Constantly changing food items to keep things fresh (Good and Bad)
Advice to Management: Good company to work overall. Ask for an area directors phone number and talk directly to them.

Title: "Fun environment, okay pay, but no promotion or pay raises"
Pros: In general the environment is fun and co-workers are really great. We work as a team and have fun while we're doing it. Easy to sell your product if you memorized the menu and were personable. Pretty good with getting time off as well.
Cons: It isn't easy to get promotions unless you're a favorite and once you do become a server there is nowhere else you can go that's up. Your pay never increases and it can be hard to make money when there are too many servers on the floor or it can get hectic when there aren't enough servers.

Title: "Applebee's Server"
Pros:
Great job if you are trying to work your way through college or need some extra spending money. It can be a great atmosphere if you work in a city suitable to your personality.
The company as a whole is a company to work for, individual restaurants may vary.
Cons: This, or any restaurant position, is not a job for the weak-hearted. Restaurants tend to bring out the worst in people, and you must learn quickly how to handle difficult clients or situations.

Title: "hostess"
Pros: fun job, fun coworkers, flexible hours
Cons: always called me and in and then let me go after just a few hours, so not worth it when my transportation costs more than one hour of work.

Title: "Fantastic"
Pros: School work life balance a plus. Strong training
Cons: Clients. Menu changes often. Tipping out when you haven't made any money yourself.

Title: "Great if you like volunterring your time"
Pros: Friendly fun environment. Great crew to work with
Cons: a LOT of work for little pay. Too many servers, you don't get enough tables to make enough. I spend a lot of time waiting for customers and a lot more time cleaning. Part time also means 4 hours or so several times a week -- i feel like I am full time because it seems like I don't have much time for anything else sonce I started this job. Too many rules too.

Title: "Good"
Pros: Its was good busy cool people nice pay
Cons: Need better management for some and better stragery

Title: "GU Volume - Mindless but easy"
Pros:
Easy job to perform daily
Low stress environment most of time
Friendly co workers every shift
Cons:
Servers don't know how to make your life easier by stacking dishes
Short staffed most of time
Advice to Management: Keep up the good work

Title: "Good solid company."
Pros: Highly focused on the guest. Committed to freshness, quality and innovation. Room for advancement if you are results driven and great with people.
Cons: Lots of changes to keep things fresh requires a lot of extra training time. Good investment but time consuming.

Title: "As Expected"
Pros: Working at this company has some significant benefits, depending on which franchise you're with. I work for the AmericanApple franchise, so my discount on food is always 50% off. Which comes in handy. The managers typically work with your schedule, if you're part time / student.
Cons: Shifts are long. No breaks. Underpaid. Tips are awful.. Applebee's typically draws lower class people b/c its so cheap. Seriously, 2 water's and a 2 for 20 deal...if lucky, you're getting a $3 tip. No thank you.
Advice to Management: better training please.

Title: "Growth Potential"
Pros: Many locations, huge growth potential through performance, great pay rates
Cons: work life balance in operations

Title: "Shennanigans"
Pros: Great part time work. Meet lots of new people. Flexible work hours...even on short notice
Cons: Small pay checks, split shifts, unequal tables per section, poor side work expectations, many call offs, managers miscounting drawers
Advice to Management: Follow headquarters precedures and give drug tests to employees

Title: "Not good to work for"
Pros: It's busy sometimes, regulars, certain managers
Cons: The whole place, treated like crap, not appreciated
Advice to Management: Treat your employees like they aren't just objects

Title: "its ok"
Pros: many positive things to say
Cons: few negative things to say

Title: "it was a job"
Pros: made decent money for a server
Cons: unprofessional management and too much drama

Title: "Great opportunity unless you have a family"
Pros: Bonus, ability to advance within.
Cons: No time for family. Servers run managers.
Advice to Management: Grow some balls

Title: "Work employees to much"
Pros: Can eat 12 $ worth of food per day
Cons: Clock employees out while still working, Does not appreciate night time workers, Mandatory meeting with NO PAY.

Title: "A lot of great friendships that were made but not in an ideal environment."
Pros: Lots of fun to work with people you like, flexible hours, decent tips
Cons: Lack of management in general, no room for growth.
Advice to Management: Treat your good employees with more respect and be willing to move people up through the company quicker

Title: "Hang out after work - you'll NEED it"
Pros: If you want to get into chain management, it's a pretty good company for that. Excellent training (you have to be a stickler), and like most chains, you'll have to relocate
Cons: I've worked in 2 AppB's and were perpetually understaffed, but that's kinda the way the business is these days
Advice to Management: To people in corporate: GET OUT OF THE OFFICE AND WORK AT A STORE BEFORE YOU COME UP WITH A NEW IDEA OR POLICY...practicality matters to your people in the trenches

Title: "Not bad"
Pros: Flexible. management is hand on
Cons: Short staffed...allow people to be lazy
Advice to Management: Take control over lazy staff members

Title: "bad management"
Pros: I enjoyed my co workers and the food is really good.
Cons: The management was terrible they were very mean and never cared about our staff
Advice to Management: be more appreciative to your employees because they do a lot for you and your business

Title: "Server @ a high tourist based chain"
Pros:
-The money can be good when it is busy.
-Have met some great people.
-My management (all but one) and GM are easily approachable.
-Discounted meals offered around scheduled shifts.
-Contest to win gift cards and stuff are often to encourage alcohol sales.
-A lot of training shifts to begin, this is good and allows you to get to know the entire menu...that is until it changes every other month.
Cons:
-Giving 2% of your sales to the bar/host even when they don't deserve it, the host not helping clean tables or skipping seating you; the bartender more interested in making their own money off tables or talking to their friends than making your guests' drinks...annoying!
-Sweeping carpet...you will learn to get better at this :(
-comps/voids highly frowned upon, even if it is the guest not liking, changing mind, etc...this can affect how often you are scheduled.
Advice to Management:
Have a cocktail server for the bar area. Nothing is more frustrating than my table getting their appetizer before their drinks, all because the bartender wants to take tables!
Being a closer seems like an incentive, until you begin your closing procedures. If the restaurant is still open and you are cleaning your BOH, you become the expo for the server or two on the floor. If it gets busy, you do nothing but help other people make money so they can leave before you and you still have your BOH and FOH to finish.

Title: "Only Work Here if It's Your Last Option"
Pros:
- Flexible schedule, which was appealing to me as a student
- Free meals when I was training others
Cons:
- Like most serving jobs, terrible pay (though tips could be all right)
- I was frequently sexually harassed by managers and other coworkers
- Lots of unpaid side work
- No benefits
Advice to Management: It's not appropriate to suggestively touch or make sexual comments to young female servers!

Title: "Great experience"
Pros: Love the money as well as co workers
Cons: The hours aren't great especially with children.
Advice to Management: Love the management

Title: "Applebee's always okay, sometimes great."
Pros: It is a nice place to go for late night apps.
Cons: It is sometimes the McDonalds of restaurants.
Advice to Management: Be more personable, top to bottom.

Title: "It was a great crew of people to work with but tough clientele."
Pros: Fun atmosphere and respecable work environment. Had a good menu and drinks.
Cons: Have to turn tables quick and often to make tips. Tips are generally low but the business generally busy. So bust your butt and you can make over 100$ night.

Title: "Woodland Group Inc. Applebee's Franchise"
Pros: They have a decent beginning salary and management benefits. They have direct deposit for managers only.
Cons: Poor training, support, and leadership.
Advice to Management: They don't care about their employees on any level. Everyone is only a tool to reach the bottom line. Very poor moral and high stress environment.

Title: "Long"
Pros: I enjoyed co workers and guest
Cons: Hours and home office is emailing 100 times the same info
Advice to Management: Let the people hire so what you hired you them to do

Title: "Short Staffed"
Pros: Most food is hand made and feels close to a real restaurant at times.
Cons: Demanding with little pay.
Advice to Management: Work on company moral.

Title: "Upbeat, fun place but demanding"
Pros: I really like the team atmosphere, the food is quality and the management is upbeat and willing to help out, even if it means washing dishes
Cons: The pay could be a bit better and they are understaffed in the back of the house by about 2-4 people
Advice to Management: Hire more people and pay about $1-2 more per hour.

Title: "It's ok, not as fun as it used to be. Need to put a focus back on people"
Pros: Company is strong and financially secure
Cons: Long hours and often micro managed, bonus program could be better
Advice to Management: listen to your people

Title: "Seen it all"
Pros: Flexible scheduling, opportunity to make good money, usually get time off if you request it, coworkers were the best part
Cons: Doing the job of 3 people for minimum wage, working ridiculously long hours, not enough money for the hours you work, company cares way more about the customer than it's employees. The turnover rate is ridiculous and it was always understaffed making it stressful for the dedicated employees.
Advice to Management: Stop being so hard on your good employees. Instead, recognize the work that they do. Stop changing the menus every two months nobody likes it. Pay more attention to employees who would make great managers. Also, give raises to the front of the house.

Title: "Decent"
Pros: Great chance to make quick money
Cons: No promotions really there are limits often 12-14 hour double shifts 5-7 days a week can have difficult and mean customers

Title: "If you like to be overworked and underpaid, this is the place to go!"
Pros: None that I can say other than customer service experience.
Cons: They want you to be a server, dust the whole restaurant, scrub toilets and if you make over 7.25 per hour, your paycheck is 0$. Not kidding.
Advice to Management: If you paid them more, perhaps they'd be happy to do restaurant maintenance and janitorial services

Title: "Worked for a Franchise"
Pros: Great people working in the stores.
Cons: The focus has gone from people/guests to pure profit. No loyalty or decent compensation to management from District Manager on down. The company has lost its passion for people.
Advice to Management: It's a people business. Take care of them. Too much of a paper chase.

Title: "working at shenanigans"
Pros: cash in-hand every shift, a good reference for other server jobs, opportunity to strengthen your skills, employee food discount, basic and simple menu
Cons: way too much work expected of the servers. you bus your own tables, roll your own silverware, a lot of people come in just to take advantage of the half-price apps. you tip the hosts just to seat you, not to help bus your tables which seems backwards to me since i thought the company paid them an hourly wage to seat the restaurant...
Advice to Management: stop changing the specials all the time. try to avoid the favoritism with the sections with the servers and split up the good tables evenly.

Title: "Horrible company to work for."
Pros: Sneaking food, decent pay, free drinks.
Cons: The horrible management, the horrible work environment.
Advice to Management: Fix how you run stuff.

Title: "Overall positive experience."
Pros: They are really flexible with schedules especially working around college/ university classes, as long as you understand that most restaurants require you to work at least partial weekends. The uniform is pretty relaxed and it was a fun, casual, place to work. Side chores always rotate and seem fair.
Cons: Depending where you work, you make your tip money mostly by quantity of tables rather than quality of tips per table, as their food is inexpensive.

Title: "A good job to get you through college."
Pros: Tips from serving can allow for you to walk away with a nice chunk of cash, discounts on food, people I worked with were awesome, and making sales was relatively easy as the food is quite good
Cons: I got burned out after working there for two and half years as it can be really stressful and difficult to deal with customers. As a result I don't ever want to work at a restaurant again. But if you're looking to have fun and make a decent amount of money while doing it, than I'd recommend working here.
Advice to Management: Keep up the good work!

Title: "Easy money with no future."
Pros: Depending on your location, (tips) you can make great money. Shifts are very flexible while you're still in school or have a 2nd job.
Cons: The money you make isn't consistent. On slow days you might work 2 hours and be sent home.
Advice to Management: The managers have a lot going on behind the scenes. Give them some more credit.

Title: "Applebee's is a great place to work"
Pros: If you are interested, it seems like it can be pretty easy for move up the ladder.
Cons: Can have long ticket times, makes guests wait too long for meal.

Title: "Not at all a bad place to work at"
Pros: plenty of hours friendly coworkers
Cons: needs new store city has grown store needs to upgrade to keep up with the demands
Advice to Management: keep up the good work

Title: "Not for the thin skinned"
Pros: competitive wage and a friendly staff
Cons: caustic managerial environment. employees typically experience being given goals and promises then management failing to follow through.

Title: "Most disorganized corporation to work for"
Pros: Flexible hours, descent tips- but definitely not good tips. Online scheduling
Cons:
High stress, disorganized and sometimes incompetent management. There was no set day the new schedule came out, managers don't even look at your availability when scheduling. There are "mandatory" meetings that management will do a poor job of announcing and you will have already requested the day off because you are moving to a new home and they will fire you for it. They will change your schedule on you the day before your shift and it is your responsibility to verify daily that you still have a shift and that it didn't get changed without your knowledge. Don't even think about getting home on time. If you're scheduled until 1145PM and have to work at 8AM the next morning at your other job, you will be at Applebee's until 2 or 3 AM, expect it. You have to pay 2% of your total sales to tipping the bartender and hosts (not a problem by me unless your guests leave a fat $0 on the tip line). Expo, the person that runs food, gets minimum wage and isn't included in the tip share, which is unfair because they work their butt's off all night for the servers for minimum wage, maybe. I worked multiple expo shifts and got server wage plus $1/hr =5.90/hr.

My particular restaurant was old and needed updating. If you think Applebee's is a clean place to eat, think again my friend. Health standards are barely followed. Don't get a lemon water, ever. Hand washing is a good practice that rarely occurs. The utensils that are used to serve the food get rinsed maybe once and put back into rotation for the next day. Look at the apron of your server- all that white stuff is your food their fingers landed in and wiped it off on their apron. I couldn't believe the minimal health standard followed by this huge corporation.
Advice to Management: If you're going to hold a standard for your employees to follow, hold yourselves to a higher standard first. If you expect the employee to care at all about the company/restaurant, give them a reason too. Don't post signs on the walls saying we need to cut down on shortage loss and then sneak by the fry bin and munch on fries all night. Post a schedule in a set location by a set day EVERY week, give employees as many opportunities to succeed and then let them go if they can't fit, but don't make it impossible to check the schedule and then fire someone for a missed shift.

Title: "Ok place to work."
Pros: They work around your schedule, provide great training and offer as many shifts as you would like, and staff is helpful.
Cons: Management picks favorites and doesn't even try to hide it, some of the management aren't sure of themselves managing and it's really easy to tell.

Title: "Great Co-Workers horrible pay"
Pros:
The Atmosphere is great
co-workers/mangers are great
Cons: you do not make enough money

Title: "Okey job for being your first"
Pros: Flexibility, can take any days off, great staff
Cons: Poor pay, tips arent good, poor hours

Title: "Applebees is great. Employee Resource group is HORRIBLE!"
Pros: Good money, meets lots of good people
Cons: Management sucks. The owners are horrible. No vacation, they ask employees to work OFF THE CLOCK
Advice to Management: Quit being selfish and bitter. The managers at the Hazard store are ridiculous .

Title: "Not a fun place to work for!"
Pros: Being around other customers and interacting with them gives off good vibes.
Cons: The benefits only go to upper management. Most employees are un trained and the training program for the job set is unnecessary for the money to be made.
Advice to Management: Consider a easier based training concept for basic servers due to all the time you put into training its far from worth the reward.

Title: "Worked at HQ: Worse professional experience of my career"
Pros: Applebee's pays well and all executives are focused on one thing and one thing only: EBITDA.
Cons: Leadership was totally erratic. DineEquity leadership shifted directions continually. Extreme lack of trust among employees. Lots of in-fighting and back stabbing. Not a place to grow personally or professionally.
Advice to Management: Try authenticity for a change. Try honesty. Try strategy. Try listening.

Title: "Fun place to work"
Pros: Coworkers and free food. Easy work. Learn customer service.
Cons: Rude customers. Low pay. Day goes by slow when there aren't many customers.

Title: "worst job!"
Pros: easy to get in...easy job, easy money. many people there take their jobs as a joke so it will be very simple work.
Cons: managment is terrible. they dont care about you at all. all they really care about is their numbers. dont even try calling off if your sick they really dont care at all.

Title: "Biggest joke of a company ever"
Pros: 4 weeks paid vacation when i was hired. They then took it down to 2 weeks for new managers and now i believe it is one week. Started off with great health benefits.
Cons: Pay is well below industry standard. Bonuses were restructured and made harder to obtain. Was maxing bonuses my first year and at they end of my 3rd they were 1/4 what they used to be. Health insurance premiums doubled and coverage went way south. Long hours. Get home at 5am and go in at 3pm. Sexual harassment was swept under the rug numerous times.
Advice to Management: I watched a server get promoted to mit, then had been a manager for 4 months got caught drinking on the job. Instead of firing him they transferred him. The store he was transferred to didnt have a km so they promoted him to km. he had absolutely no kitchen experience. He forgot to order steaks for mothers day. This is what happens at applebees. My advice is run as quickly as you can.

Title: "Applebee's"
Pros: The money you make from tips has the potential to be good provided you know what you're doing and treat the guests well.Also, the strict rules and procedures of the company help, in the long run, anyone who is jut starting in the restaurant business. You can work your way up into corporate if you do work hard enough and become dedicated enough. I was lucky to have a very caring manager who recognized the effort I put into my work.
Cons: Sometimes the strict rules set in place can be difficult to follow. This is corporate so you are just a number in a big system. The district manager even said in a meeting, "If you want to leave then leave, you are replaceable." It i easy to build a strong relationship with your manager and if you're lucky, you'll find one that becomes almost like another parent to you but any higher than that and they don't care about your work.

Title: "Lost company, focusing on all the wrong things."
Pros: There are a lot of locations, so you can pretty much find one close to home. I really do like D.O.'s.
Cons: The training program for management is horrible. They want it to be self-lead, which id great, if they give you a way to find the answers. The managers I worked alongside were extremely unprofessional and HR knows it, but keeps them on, even when they break the law. There are guidelines each schedule should adhere to, but they don't follow them. Every GM I worked with sat in the office instead of being out on the floor. When asked for constructive criticism, they would never give feedback. Manager evaluations are to be done frequently, I never got one, no matter how many times I asked. A lot of pettiness and overall immature ways of doing business. Told by my gm to lie about things, including things that could make people sick. Constant sexual harassment even when repeatedly being told to stop. 60 hour work weeks, no overtime.
Advice to Management: Take more pride in the managers you hire. Stop letting the guests and other managers walk all over us. Have some standards that make sense and are enforced.

Title: "Applebee's has allowed me to work a flexible schedule"
Pros: I've been at Applebee's long enough that I basically feel as if I work with my second family. My managers have always been very flexible with my schedule, which has allowed me to go to school and spend quality time with my family.
Cons: Secret shoppers are the worst. We are encouraged to use a scripted dialogue with our guests to upsell certain items, and although I can see this would be valuable to someone who is uncomfortable talking to strangers, for me it is simply irritating. I don't feel its appropriate to annoy my guest by suggesting a drink, appetizer, and dessert when they know what they want. However because Applebee's participates in the secret shopper program we have no choice but to assume each guest is a secret shopper and be sure to suggest items or we can be punished by being placed in our secondary position or have our hours reduced due to a poor score on a shop. Like I said, I do see the value of the secret shopper program, however if my guest enjoys my service, has a meal delivered in a timely manner which they enjoy, I think there should be an option for them to say, she didn't suggest a darn thing but she wowed me so don't punish this server.

Title: "Server at Applebees"
Pros: your basic serving job. Good for a job while working through school.
Cons: Not very flexible with schedules. Leave it up to you to get people to work for you even if they schedule you on a day your had previously requested off.

Title: "Fun place, to many waitresses"
Pros: Management is alot of fun and very motivating when it comes to your performance as a server
Cons: To many servers on the floor limits your earning potential significantly
Advice to Management: Dont overcompensate and faith that you trained your employees well

Title: "Great"
Pros: We're all really a big family. We may have our issues from time to time, but we come together as a team and make everything work out. Applebuddies!
Cons: If the store is low on staff it make it a little more difficult and if everyone isn't communication then problems will pop up, but really it's the best place I've worked I love it here!

Title: "Fun job with the potential to earn good money."
Pros: Good pay for a college student, $8 and hour plus about $7 to $8 an hour in tips. This is a good job for someone who is going to college, or just some extra spending cash, wouldn't be a good career though. Fun work environment, always something interesting going on. Most co-workers are nice and depending on how often you work it really feels like a little family. Flexible hours. SOME room for advancement depending on what position you start out at. Management is very relaxed as long as you do what you are supposed to.
Cons: Can be very long hours, without ANY breaks at all. You never know what time you are going to get off, you may be scheduled to leave at 8 o'clock and end up being there until 11 or 12. Tips can be unreliable, ranging from $2 a day to $140 in my case. No benefits. Food discounts are very stingy (only 25% off). I personally don't mind, but if you are sensitive the kitchen is a place for all kinds of crude jokes and sexual harassment at times. The people you work with can be very unreliable and you end up getting punished for their mistakes, if someone doesn't show up for their shift while you're working, you will have to stay to cover their shift.
Advice to Management: Give people breaks, working on your feet for 9+ hours is exhausting and results in poor customer service. Improve the food discount, hungry workers are not good workers. Provide some way we can communicate with district managers.

Title: "This is the worst job I have ever had."
Pros: I have a part-time job.
Cons: The servers are rude and nasty and don't do their jobs.
Advice to Management: I'm not even sure where to start.

Title: "No Breaks , low pay"
Pros: Hostesses got tip share
Cons: No breaks what-so-ever , management played favorites, hostesses were stuck doing everything that host, servers, bus-boys and cleaning workers job descriptions entailed but did not reflect in pay ( work extremely hard for base pay). And 8 -10 shifts with no breaks/lunch
Advice to Management: Treat everyone equally, and stick with the job description. It's not fair to say "and other assigned duties" when those duties are other employees responsibilities. Get rid of toxic, lazy workers and give your hard working employees breaks!

Title: "Customers were cruel from time to time, the staff was generally pretty good."
Pros: Staff was supportive and helpful
Cons: Customers were often annoying and the job is tiring.

Title: "Good people to work with"
Pros: I love to come to work in actually like being around the employee's I work with.
Cons: Long hours are require but pass that its a great company to move up in the pyramid.

Title: "NO RESPECT FOR EMPLOYEES"
Pros: 50 percent off food and long hours
Cons: EVERYTHING, unset schedules, never get any breaks, Neighborhood experts are hard on trainees, managers like talk to their employees like they are scums. THe pay sucks. THE turnover rate is high for a reason.

Title: "mediocre at best."
Pros: Schedule is flexible. Accommodating to physical abilities. Time off is easily taken if requested at least 1 week in advance. The staffing software used is helpful in giving up/picking up shifts.
Cons: The software used to put in orders is atrocious. Complete overhaul is needed. At this particular location, favoites are given select sections and side work is not evenly distributed.

Title: "Three stores, nine years. Abused, used, and broken."
Pros: When you have a boss that enables you to succeed, you can be proud of the work you do on the day by day. You can put in the extra hours and enjoy praise from your peers. It's easy to keep a great attitude when you're backed by a great boss that cares about his store and is equally as proud of the hard work his team puts in. That boss creates an atmosphere of family, and makes the job a fun-filled, great place to work.
Cons: Promised promotions, even began training and took on responsibilities for middle management, then suddenly replaced by someone with no prior affiliation to the company. Happened twice across the span of three different stores. Watched a lot of hard working employees ridiculed by management for "being lazy" or "long ticket times" when management wouldn't even step across the line to lend a hand.
Advice to Management: When you work in a high-stress environment such as this, it's important to keep your employees happy. Instead of ostracizing your staff when they "under perform", perhaps it would be better to try and find the problem and suggest several methods to fix it. (Remembering a simple "please" and "thank you" in these situations goes a long way toward getting these guys to actually want to do the work) Management could definitely use some sort of class on how to diffuse tense situations. It'd also be nice to get a little communication and feedback about areas of improvement, to replace the talking with other employees behind their backs with derogatory comments and childish jokes. Long story short, though, when my old boss enabled me to succeed, it wasn't hard to find those extra things to do because I cared as much about the store and the job I was doing to always go that extra mile. On the other hand, a boss that will only tell you about how bad you are doing and how lazy you are kinda makes you want to be that much more lazy. Honestly, most of us are making close to minimum wage here. Being treated like adults on a consistent basis and not spoken to like children or treated like an out-of-control high school classroom should definitely be in the job description.

Title: "Forgettable"
Pros: Consistent supply of tables; able to work many hours if needed.
Cons: Due to the location of the store the customers were less than desirable. You could make the same amount of money as in a restaurant with reputable customers because the store was always so busy but you had to wait on three times the amount of tables. The managers were rarely willing to get their hands dirty. Most at my store stayed in the office unless corporate was supposed to show up and you got attitude if you had to go bother them for a problem. This location was the joke of the town mostly because of how it was run from top to bottom.
Advice to Management: I was a key hourly and was thrown to the wolves by the management staff. More training would be greatly needed for the success of someone in this position.

Title: "grueling long hours"
Pros: You get hired on the spot.
Cons: You will never have a lunch break even if you work a double shift. Managers are encouraged to be rude to employees. You never know what time you are going home. Hours change weekly and your pay in tips are hidden from you until payday!
Advice to Management: Give employees 10 minutes at least to eat. Don't eat in front of hungry employees. Don't send employees to drive and buy the restaurant supplies. Give the same respect you expect.

Title: "Fine for a little, but nowhere to spend years of your life."
Pros: The staff was for the most part pleasant as were our customers. Managers were okay, but not the best.
Cons: not much room for advancement, a lack of knowledge of where one employees job ended and the other began, and general lack of care about customers. Also, low pay for anyone who wasn't serving. Maybe this accounted for the lack of teamwork

Title: "Hostess, to go, server, bartender"
Pros: Good money. Flexible schedule while in college. Room to advance to better shifts, sections, and positions.
Cons: Management doesn't stand behind their employees. No automatic gratuity for large parties. Low checks means turnover is more important than quality in order to make money.
Advice to Management: Show some gratitude for the work and patience your employees have.

Title: "Worst job of all time."
Pros: working with friends, tip outs every night, nice guests, free sodas and food sometimes, knowing how behind the scenes is
Cons: Crowded, no one cares about you, bussing, terrible managers, never being cut, staying past 12 in the morning, meeting
Advice to Management: Choose managers a lot better. Most of them don't actually care about the guests or their employees. Work with them to be more professional and cut down on the swearing. When someone is sick at work, let them go home.

Title: "Interesting"
Pros: Co workers are like family, awesome people!
Cons: If your not a favorite you will not advance if you do not advance you make NO money
Advice to Management: Realize people have lives outside of applebees and you only serve food your not saving lives!

Title: "It is a descent job as restaurants go."
Pros: It can be a fun place to work.
Cons: Having to close (ie: get out at 3 am) and in the same week be there at 5 am for inventory. It makes having any kind of normal sleep schedule impossible.

Title: "Not good"
Pros: Just A Job nothig special.
Cons: Its who you know not y ur ability
Advice to Management: Be objective and reward performance.

Title: "Would not recommend"
Pros: nice coworkers, decent tips,
Cons: no one shows up for work
Advice to Management: Hire competent people

Title: "Stressful work environment that has poor structure across multiple franchises"
Pros: Tips are the best part of this job and every day is interesting at the very least. The people you work with are maybe the best part, but only because you share the same distaste for this place.
Cons: They try to get you to work off the clock which is ridiculous as most of your pay comes from tips. Why would I stay after you clock me out without my knowledge? Dishonest and just bad business.
Advice to Management: Pay management more because I have not met a manager that did not have one foot out the door.

Title: "It was...ok"
Pros:
Cash in your pocket
Worked with a lot of good people
Excellent experience in building confidence
Flexible hours
Cons:
Some management staff need a better understanding on how to lead
Sometimes you just aren't going to get tipped

Title: "Mt pleasant, Michigan"
Pros: This place gave me an opportunity to advance, they recognized hard work. I've made very close friends, and it has a family-like environment. I'm glad to work for this company even if I walk away hating it some days. Also very rewarding.
Cons: Very fast paced, challenging work load not for sissy' turnover rate is terrible, college kids don't care but make up 85% of the staff.
Advice to Management: Make me one. RK ;P

Title: "Don't expect to make any money"
Pros: There are multiple positions to choose from at this company and the hours are flexible
Cons: The customers are cheap and rude, you need to work constant double shifts to make any money. But if you get close to our 40 hours expect to be kicked out mid shift.
Advice to Management: Treat your staff with respect and think ahead when making the schedule. It isn't fair to make a person work a double with no break in between to eat or sit down.

Title: "Challenging and constantly evolving."
Pros: Good opportunities to learn a lot and assume new responsibilities. Large number of high volume restaurants and good training programs in place.
Cons: Very large and frequently changing menu makes constant training of staff vital to maintain adequate menu knowledge and food preparation standards. This is not a good environment to become complacent in.
Advice to Management: See what is going on in the restaurant instead of relying on the word of trusted employees. Trust but verify. Consider the cost of training to replace skilled employees when giving our merit raises.

Title: "It's a job"
Pros: Nice organization structure, and they provided incentives.
Cons: Everybody else complained about being there, and the training was ridiculous.
Advice to Management: Devise a more efficient training strategy.

Title: "Great Brand"
Pros: Flexible work schedule was nice
Cons: Constant Changes made teams scramble

Title: "Great place, great people, terrible pay"
Pros: The people who worked at Applebee's were outstanding and remarkable people. The environment was relaxed but still professional. Management was friendly, competent and flexible with scheduling accommodations. Excellent if you are looking for part-time work to pocket some cash.
Cons:
Living on less than $3 an hour and tips is just not possible where I worked (It barely covers what you will owe in taxes after claiming tips.) Unless you are being employed at an Applebee's that is very popular all the time, you will not be able to afford working there if you also live in an expensive area. (Such as the Greater Boston Area)

With $4.5 billion worth of sales just from last year in 2013 alone, you would hope some of that money could go towards paying your 28,000 employees a little better.
Advice to Management: Keep being friendly, keep everything relatively the same; fight harder for better wages for your employees.

Title: "Nice experience"
Pros: Nice stuff, flexible schedule, fun management, overall a pleasant experience. Restaurant is always packed, never a dull moment. Helpful people.
Cons: After training they expect you to have a full section. If you dont get the system, then bye bye. Although, If they see some potential they'll be more willing to train you longer. Previous experience is very much recommended. Very complicated POS for a beginner.

Title: "Alot of pressure"
Pros: It was a good job as far as tip wise. A great atmosphere to work in. Oh and great foood also.
