You get to meet new people each day and best of all you will be come nicer from having this job! When you are payed to be nice to people, it becomes a habit.
Cons: Getting a job at Applebee's can be difficult, if you have connections use them. Also, it is not the best restaurant for getting a discount on the food, unless you are a cook you pay close to full price for each item.
Advice to Management: Keep doing what you are doing.

Title: "Depends on Management"
Pros: Very flexible schedules, servers can make quick money, it is very easy to pick up shifts if you need money.
Cons: Management can be condescending and rude, customers can be rude, there is little room for advancement. It is also hard to get raises.
Advice to Management: Respect your employees

Title: "Good opportunity for hardworking people."
Pros: I've been working for Applebee's for a year and a half now. I like how my managers and co-workers work as a team. I've learn a lot from the restaurant industry and I had the opportunity to work in the kitchen, as a server and even hosting. It's a restaurants that believes in your hard work and dedication.
Cons: Like any other restaurant, you have good days, and bad days. But as long as you're a hard worker and always taking good care of you're guest, you always make good money.
Advice to Management: Always give opportunities to you're dedicated employees to move forward.

Title: "Good coworkers, useless management"
Pros: Not bad money for working at a restaurant. Time went by fast because of how fast paced the job was.. a 12 hour shift would feel like a 6 hour shift. Had the coolest most easygoing coworkers. Usually had 40 hours a week and hours were stable resulting in a decent paycheck.
Cons: Terrible management that liked to micromanage everything. Management treated most employees like disposable trash. Management liked who they liked and disliked who they disliked, it didn't matter how hard you worked, if management didn't like you, you would be treated with disrespect and scheduled the worst hours. In many occasions, the employees that were slower and did not care got the better hours and more respect than the ones that worked their butt off. New rollout added many new sandwiches to menu which made things more complicated during lunch. Corporate had strict rules about labor and food costs that had to be followed.. our store had very high turnover, so the food costs were fairly bad, which reflected on everyone. The raises were frozen for 6 months and still haven't been given up to the day I left. Some people were there for a year and a half and still didn't get a single raise. Most of management didn't care about their employees, just the bottom line, which was actually counterproductive because many didn't work very hard because management would find fault whether they worked hard or not. The words "good job" barely existed except between coworkers
Advice to Management: You can make much more money if you respect your employees based on things such as work ethic, skills at the job, keeping cool during rushes, always being on time and never calling off, etc.. NOT based on if you like them or not. Focusing on the bottom line is fine but you should at least respect your employees and say good job once in awhile. Try to have meetings and talk to your employees about how they are doing, not yelling at them during rushes because you cut most of the coworkers to get that labor bonus.

Title: "Okay for the first three weeks, then drama."
Pros: Met fun people, decent new store opening.
Cons: Long hours, managers stealing and sleeping with employees, area directors convicted of felonies, crooked company in general. Only a discount when working on shift (2-3 dollars max).
Advice to Management: Clean up your company's management.

Title: "It is fun, but provo is terrible money."
Pros: fun, flexible and the hours are great for students.
Cons: tips can be bad, over staffed.

Title: "Over worked/under paid"
Pros: Great corporate training, fun atmosphere, it's almost like a family
Cons: Work employees to death, side work is long and troublesome compared to other industries. Hours are long and no breaks are given. Was required to attend shift meetings without being compensated.
Advice to Management: Treat your employees as a family. No need to undermine them. It's a team, so help us out instead of spending the rush in the office.

Title: "Great opportunities"
Pros: Salary was fantastic for the amount of work and type of work I was doing
Cons: Management support was not there.
Advice to Management: Be able to back up your promises

Title: "Managers are Slaves"
Pros: You don't have to have a life outside of work. You will get to train new managers all the time. Check to want ads they is almost always a job posted.
Cons: Unwilling to keep up facilities, pressure to profit over freshness. The structure of management at store level puts the very best managers with the very worst in hopes of help improve weak manager. What you get are managers who steal and feed friend for free while hard working managers suffer with poor performing P&Ls..Unwilling to fire minorities for even the gravest offences.
Advice to Management: Go back to school and get your degree.

Title: "Good job for college student!"
Pros:
Flexible hours, then you have set schedule
Nice people
Pretty good tips
Very clean working environment
Cons: This just wasn't the position for me. I'm not necessarily a people person so it was the wrong choice.
Advice to Management: Not so much favoritism

Title: "Busy work for nothing pay"
Pros: busy, people, other wise mostly negitave
Cons: after the hours i was being paid about $10 an hour on my salary

Title: "Server at applebees"
Pros:
- Flexible schedule
- Fun enviornment
Cons:
- Slow during the day
- New managers all the time
- Too many servers working at once
- Cheap customers

You can work a whole shift and get only 1 table if it's slow

Title: "Horrific"
Pros: Very Flexible Schedule. Good way to make some extra cash.
Cons: Get stuck with horrible hours, little to no room for advancement, managers like to play favorites when writing schedules. was trainer for a year and a half and I got screwed on hours and scheduling every single week because the scheduling manager had some weird grudge against me because I wasn't going to bow to their every whim and treat them like some deity. Customers are rude and often don't tip meaning that you just lost money since you now have to tip out on what you didn't make
Advice to Management: Burn it down. Start over.

Title: "Okay for people who are flexible and like surprises."
Pros:
*It's like a family, everyone is so kind & gets along.
*Pay can range from $7-$10..so when it's high, it's a good feeling (only happens when you're the only host)
*It's pretty easy, almost too easy actually.
Cons:
*You don't have a set schedule. Some days you can work 2 hours or some days you could work 7. Sometimes you can work 3 days, and some 6.
*Management pretends to care, but I actually don't see them on the floor a lot.
*Tipouts depend on how busy the place is, which it's pretty bad when it's a slow season.
*Servers treat you like slaves, expecting you to buss their table, when you only need to get the plates.

Title: "Typical restaurant, great $, terrible hours, awful management"
Pros: $, flexible schedule with college classes, anyone can work there.
Cons: Hours, "seedy crowd", drunks, no tips, management, drugs.
Advice to Management: Quit

Title: "Server, Host, GU"
Pros: Applebee's has a laid back atmosphere and there are usually plenty of hours to work
Cons: Unorganized service strategy compared to other restaurants, like Red Lobster. Also, their management was catty and unprofessional.
Advice to Management: Advice to high level management: Spend more time hiring more skilled and professional foh and boh managers. No divas should be permitted.

Title: "Decent"
Pros: Not terrible for a service industry job
Cons: went franchise so then it sort of went down

Title: "Coworkers make this job because the company as a whole is not appreciative to its employees."
Pros: The menu is easy to learn. Pay checks are guaranteed although most servers get next to nothing on theirs.
Cons: This company cuts hours and looks for ways to cut corners, even shafting the employees to get ahead at times.

Title: "Great entry to service industry"
Pros:
-Pays minimum plus tips even though not legally required, at least in my store

-Thorough training. They push you to excel at service

-Moves people up as quickly as possible. Hosts move up to the next step typically in 4-6 months, to server in under a year and if you're interested in management this is well within the realm of possibility as well.

-Flexible scheduling with understanding management. Great for college students and people with other jobs

-Busy place where servers can make good money, probably the best in town

-Will give great references to good employees and will help you transfer to another store if needed
Cons:
-Management can be a bit disorganized, though no worse than anywhere else

-Corporate feel can be a bit tiring. Lots of rules to follow, push for getting customers to fill out surveys and do promos, though staff is rewarded for doing well at this
Advice to Management: Get scheduling done further out. I typically don't know what my schedule is more than a week out which makes things difficult to plan for and can be a bit frustrating.

Title: "Server"
Pros:
-Great customer service experience
-Great managers
-Great people to work with
-Great practice for working in a high paced environment
Cons:
-Very pressured to perform
-Lots of negative reinforcement
Advice to Management: Use more positive reinforcement than negative. It will make the employees want to do better for you and will keep them from talking bad about you behind your back. It will also help them be excited to come to work instead of dreading it because of fear.

Title: "Fast paced but fun experience"
Pros:
tips...
helpful staff. I liked being able to help the customers out with their orders.
Cons:
stressful at times but with the right attitude its not that bad.
if part time the hours are not too bad....so if it is too stressful for you you can look on the Brightside it is only for a few hours a day
Advice to Management: doing a good job

Title: "Poor management with no teamwork"
Pros: The only real benefit of working for Applebee's that I have found is brand recognition. I'm really having to try to think of anything else.... no. That's it.
Cons: Poor management, worse training, no teamwork, no consistency, horrible cleanliness, constant mistakes, poor planning and prep, always playing catch up.
Advice to Management: Take some time to sit down and develop a plan that you can use to make your restaurant a success. Make a daily build to for your prep and make sure that you are fully prepared for the following shift. Create and follow realistic staffing guidelines to ensure that you are meeting your guests needs. Most importantly work as a team. Nothing ensures that your employees will not care like constant complaining about the other members of the management staff and whining about how poorly everything is run. Be the example. Show your crew how to be a team. We are all here to work together and make money. Be the example.

Title: "Waiter/Server"
Pros:
- Leave with money in your pocket
- Opportunity to make money based off of how quickly you can turn tables
Cons:
- Unorganized
- Team members are usually lazy causing you to have to pick up the slack
Advice to Management: Look to hire workers with some sort of credibility of having been able to complete a task

Title: "It was fun while it lasted."
Pros: I loved the people I worked with.
Cons: The managers thought they were amazing.

Title: "hostess"
Pros: the house were pretty flexible
Cons: the management was pretty bad sometimes

Title: "Ignorance and laziness at it's finest...."
Pros: There are not any positive things to say
Cons: Too many problems to list.
Advice to Management: I would recommend going back to school in the hopes of obtaining some sort of business sense of mind.

Title: "The worst job of my life"
Pros: There are no good reasons unless you do not already have a job
Cons: Everything from schedualing to the location to the type of people that come in there. You work you butt off for nothing.
Advice to Management: Get out of the office and help if your only going to have 1 sever and 1 cook because your tryihng to save labor/

Title: "Loved it!"
Pros: Tips, Constant changes to bring people in, good group of people to work with
Cons: Sharing tips with hostesses and bartenders
Advice to Management: Act like managers, no favortism, and no throwing tantrums!

Title: "Great"
Pros: Wonderful place to work at
Cons: N/A because there are no cons

Title: "Good starting job for a high school student"
Pros: Great flexibility in the work schedule, quick money making opportunity, great opportunity to get your foot in the door in the restaurant industry.
Cons: Too much staff, leaving you with few tables to wait on and little money to make.
Advice to Management: Acknowledge your hard-working employees, try to encourage management to avoid having "favorites"

Title: "Disappointing"
Pros: Money is decent for a serving job.
Cons: Does not recognize hard work. Management is lazy.

Title: "Dull"
Pros: Applebee's is a nice company, franchised. Some room for growth.
Cons: Amature system of management. In consistent hours. No raises.
Advice to Management: See cons.

Title: "Love helping the guest"
Pros: Connecting with guest, lots of shifts available
Cons: turnover rate is very high
Advice to Management: Show a little more respect and concern for employees.

Title: "Great job when learning to interact with people"
Pros:
Tips are always good.
Flexible schedule, can pick up shifts or give them away when you want.
Always moving around and time flies as a result.
Cons:
Always have to be present in your job to receive maximum tips.
Around food all day, could be a good or bad thing.
Pushed to upsell products from the menus all the time.
Advice to Management: Treat your employees better. Encouragement is always better than criticizing and improves the morale of your staff. Turnover is already high as it is.

Title: "Rookie job"
Pros: good people, good for beginners for servers and bartenders, easy staff to work with. Easy job all around.
Cons: no money for what you deal with. Clientele is hit or miss on a daily basis. Most people are rude and treat you like you're unworthy.
Advice to Management: Management is always good.

Title: "Used to be fun. Now a nightmare"
Pros: Fun co-workers and fun interacting with interesting customers.
Cons: No employee loyalty. Will fire anyone for any reason. Hypocritical higher ups. (Look up Applebee's pastor on google)
Advice to Management: Show more respect for employees.

Title: "I was a cook for three years."
Pros: The job itself didn't require much skill and got to work with some great friends. I also got raises fairly quickly.
Cons: Working in a food service job sucks. The hours suck. The work sucks. A lot of the time the people suck. Also working for a corporation means that you have to jump through hoops and play stupid little games to actually get anything accomplished.
Advice to Management: Work on hiring better employees to begin with so that the turnover rate was lower. I had to train so many people to watch them leave a month later. Waste of my life.

Title: "Happy"
Pros: There were alot of very Nice people and the pay matched the amount that you have worked. Co workers made job more fun
Cons: it was pretty stresful and there was alot of work to do. theres nothing i can really do but it doesnt mean much to them if you make it or not

Title: "Mass Exodus of Managers in Atlanta"
Pros: Mostly good staff, but a few bad 'apples'. Ummmm?
Cons: Upper Level Mgmt has no idea what they are doing. Ignoring repairs, ignoring company policy, cutting the throats of GM's - watch them leave in mass. Policy of having a 'write-up' on every employee so you can fire them at will is simply Bad Policy. Working Mgrs 80+ hours for a bonus that is ever changing and unattainable is bad policy. Paying GMs 0 dollars more than an Asst Mgr is ridiculous. Every single restaurant job I had was better than being a GM in this Franchise!
Advice to Management: When you buy a batch of stores from the original founder of the company - clean house at the upper level. You guys (and I mean the ones that actually should be fired) are squeezing out GMs as if it was them. Once all the GMs are gone.....then who will they blame?

Title: "Consistently inconsistent"
Pros: I worked for both corporate owned and franchised locations and to be completely honest, the franchise store were much better run that the company stores. I worked with some great General Managers and I've worked with some people who let a tiny bit of power go straight to their head. It really depends on the store.
Cons: Quality of life is low. Poorly written manager schedules leave you frequently sleep deprived. I would work a close mid open at least once a week in spite of the company guidelines given during orientation stating this is to happen only in extermis. 60+ hour weeks are common. Stores run for months with 2 managers. Bonus is based on sales over last year but consideration is not given for mitigating circumstances. Deferred maintenance seems to be the norm. I worked at one store that flooded in the kitchen every Sunday for a year before we were allowed to have more than Roto-rooter look at it. Unsafe and sometimes unsanitary conditions are allowed to go on because they are too expensive to fix. Managers are expected to do landscaping and repairs in their "spare time".
Advice to Management: I realize you are a great big company but maybe look into having someone local to maintain the stores in each region. Listen to your managers. Let them do their jobs. Don't expect them to do construction/maintenance work.

Title: "horrible political waste of time"
Pros: Flexible schedule, decent pay, sometimes fun atmosphere
Cons: managers dont hold employees accountable for actions

Title: "High Pressure, poor training for Server position"
Pros: The money was good, and the place was always busy. I was making $400 in tips Thursday through Sunday. Can't think of any other pros.
Cons: The training was insufficient. Not enough to train a server. The trainer had zero incentive for me to succeed, and it showed. Politics were nuts. I came off the street. Other folks, hosts for instance, had wanted to be servers for a while, so they didn't appreciate management selecting me over them.
Advice to Management: Train better.

Title: "Good enough job to just get by."
Pros: Not a very difficult job, definitely not rocket science.
Cons: Getting shifts can be difficult. The only ways to make a lot of tips money is to work during the weekday nights and working doubles.

Title: "Long Hours"
Pros: a lot of fun people to work around along with decent pay and opportunities to expand your knowledge of resturant life.
Cons: Long work hours and a bonus struscture that is nearly impossible to achieve. Very hard work with little reward. Needs to work on upper management communication skills along with proper work ethics.
Advice to Management: Take care of your associates. Happy workers equals more money

Title: "My Take"
Pros: Store/GM Specific, however, leave an hour early if it's slow...coworkers usually scratch your back as long as you scratch theirs. Potential to Bonus every quarter.
Cons: Scheduling, alot of close/opens. close shifts prior to your weekend. Managament not on the same page...no consistensy. Not enough time in a shift to do administrative work, schedules, interviews, etc. Labor budget & staffing can be extremely challenging. I find the salary is off by a few thousand.
Advice to Management: My advice would be, take more time with your management schedules. Quality of life is a huge factor in wanting to stay or go in this company.

Title: "The bee's knees"
Pros:
Amazing people to work with, every one knows every one
Cash in pocket is always nice
Can be cross trained to earn more money.
Cons:
Tips are way too unstable as a host you could make 30$ you could make 10$
seems with people come a lot of Drama (Drama-bees)
New managers every month it seems like
Advice to Management: Applebees is an amazing place to work, it was my first job but some advice try to keep managers for as long as possible and try to give the hosts a little more base pay.

Title: "Great place"
Pros: Discount on food. Fun environment.
Cons: A lot of manager turnover
Advice to Management: Listen to employees.

Title: "It was a fun place to work. But I never want to work in the restaurant industry again."
Pros: Applebee's was just an overall fun place to work. The food was good, so selling the products was pretty easy as long as you knew what you were talking about. The individuals I worked with also added to a great environment and made it an enjoyable job.
Cons: It is a restaurant, so if you can work restaurants or as a server, great! It seemed like perfection was expected of employees, which isn't a bad thing, except employees weren't rewarded accordingly.
Advice to Management: I think the biggest problem I had was the base pay. Most of the time, I never took any of that home, it all went to taxes.

Title: "Applebees"
Pros: Small franchise in Atlanta (40 stores) so you new the upper management and they new you. Promotions are performance based, not by seniority. So bust your but and you can go far. I went from manager trainee to GM in less than 2 years. Fun atmosphere to work in.
Cons: If your in the restaurant management business than there is the usual b.s. at Applebees

Title: "Concerned for Company Future"
Pros: They provide attainable bonus goals and allow for time off when needed.
Cons:
The training program for hourly and management is disorganized and spotty. There is no "program". They give you an overview of the job and then you are on your own.
      The higher ups push and push for good reviews from guests but don't pay attention to providing detailed standards and protocols to be followed (spec.). There is no "right way" of doing things for us to learn or fall back on to uphold standards. This makes it very difficult to direct and know what is expected.
        The support center does not follow through on projects we request of them. It is increasingly difficult to get into contact with them due to the cut backs made. They are clearly over burdened.
        The home office leads with a rod instead of a carrot. It is rare to feel the work you do is valued and appreciated. Their work horses are breaking because of it.
Advice to Management: Food and Service Standards need to be put into place- not just cleanliness, but a means to create a lasting culture. We need direction and a real mission statement that holds the purpose for the company. Thank and appreciate your employees. We are not just working for money, though that helps. We need to feel we are valued and that we have something to work for. A real training progam needs to be created. One that has organization and direction, not just a book to fill out. A trainee should not be expected to train themself.

Title: "Good for some extra money in the bank account, but the in the words of my interviewer, "It's not a career.""
Pros:
When you eat there either before your shift or during your break, you get employee discounts on the food.

For a restaurant job, the pay isn't that bad, and all the servers' tips are pooled.
Cons: The main problem was with my location in Ridley Park, but the managers never seemed to communicate with one another.

Title: "Great co-workers but terrible pay."
Pros: Loved working with most of the people there. It made for a fun work environment.
Cons: The clientele of Applebees is typically a cheaper bad attitude type crowd. You work really hard and won't receive a 10% tip. Lots of times you won't receive a tip on $50+ tickets. Management will try to tell you it is your fault that your not making enough money even though majority of the problems servers have are kitchen or food packaging related. Not service.
Advice to Management: Listen to your top employees and actually deal with the customers and know what the customers want. Don't micromanage and look at the big picture. (They loved to get onto guys about a shirt that was wrinkled or sleeves that were rolled up but wouldn't pay attention to inventory or customers needs)

Title: "Decent work, don't rely on it."
Pros: Decent wage compared to retail. Potential to make money.
Cons: Unreasonable investments on returns, fluctuating hours, rigid system.
Advice to Management: Place people according to ability.

Title: "Good so far but I am still in training"
Pros: good benefits, nice employees, good food
Cons: could start line cooks out at more then what they do

Title: "Was not a good experience"
Pros: Did not have to claim all cash tips.
Cons: Was "suspended" and then fired because I could not get to work (45 mins away) in a blizzard and no one could cover for me (it was a double shift) so two strikes = fired!
Advice to Management: Have a little common sense.

Title: "The people are amazing, management as people are cool, as managers.. they need work."
Pros: The people here are amazing. We really feel like a family here. I can't say enough about the awesome staff.
Cons: You have to work 1800 hours in a year in order to receive benefits. Management needs to listen to employee suggestions more. We know more about the way the kitchen should be handled than they do.
Advice to Management: Forget about the stupid cutting gloves. They are entirely useless. Worry more about the hazards in the kitchen that need immediate attention.

Title: "good money"
Pros: good money serving, flexible hours, time off easy to get
Cons: weekends, long hours, customers, service job
Advice to Management: strict

Title: "Poor mgmt in the midwest, really driven and serious in the south"
Pros: In the south, thyere very goal driven and will teach you various positions. In the midwest, the mgrs were lazy and trash.
Cons: In the south, they worked you to the bone! In the midwest, the stores were never stocked and staff never arrived prepared to work...if they showed at all.
Advice to Management: Apple Gold and Green Apple need to get together and share some tips.

Title: "ask to much"
Pros: always going to be busy so you'll make $
Cons: no vacation bad management and they ask to much for what they pay
Advice to Management: care for your employees

Title: "Friendly Environment"
Pros: as a host its a pretty chill job as long as u do the basic requirements, the people i work with make the job worth going to
Cons: management/promotion process is a little screwy

Title: "Corporate offices are struggling with culture, work load and direction"
Pros:
Very good pay. Applebee's corporate offices will pay better than most KC employers. Benefits are also solid. Plus, leadership makes sure that all bonus-eligible employees actually get their bonuses -- 100 percent, every year.
Director and below positions are filled with a lot of smart, very dedicated people.
Cons:
The cons outweigh even a big paycheck, sorry to say. The culture is toxic. Almost no one enjoys working here, which is tough to face day in and day out. The work force has been cut back so badly that we are all doing more than one job. (Proportionally, we're underpaid.) But it's not the long hours and lack of work-life balance that gets most people. It's the culture. It's very hierarchal, with random decisions being made from the parent company, DineEquity. Dine does an incredibly poor job of communicating anything to Applebee's.

As a result, roles are not clearly defined. Allegiances shift constantly because the entire workforce is always unsure what the direction is on any given day. A lot of wasted work happens at the parent company and Applebee's. Very, very frustrating.
Advice to Management:
Staff up. Listen to the rank and file. A lot of lip service has been paid to doing so, but there is no evidence that it's really happened.
Realize that your current business model is absolutely not sustainable. In the end, the shareholders will pay.

Title: "Bad managers make it terrible."
Pros:
1.) Tips.
2.) Food is good.
3.) Free drinks during your shift.
Cons:
1.) Terrible managers that didn't seem to care about guiding you.
2.) Paying out tips to a grumpy bar-tender.
3.) Server pay unless it's a higher-end establishment.
Advice to Management: Seriously try to improve team morale. Be on the floor more if something arises (such as a customer NOT listening to the fact you can't do a Sunday deal on a Saturday).

Title: "fast paced, busy store"
Pros: it was $.50/hr more then i was making before
Cons: it still doesn't pay the bills
Advice to Management: RDs don't always have to be dicks, with nothing nice to say to anyone ever

Title: "Things change"
Pros: Applebee's International was a very different place to work when Abe Gustin was at the helm. It felt like a family work environment. We were professional but still were able to have a lot of fun. I can still hear Larry's voice coming over the intercom on days that they decided to let us go early. Once Abe was shoved out of the picture, at was all about money and the bottom line.
Cons: They are now owned by I-Hop that wants to franchise every Applebee's restaurant. Bottom line is the only thing that matters, not matter what they put the restaurant worker's through. The will penny pinch them to death.
Advice to Management: Get back to Abe's way. It was a well known fact that if he came into a restaurant he was to be treated just like any other customer. He didn't get seated before any customer that was waiting before him. He was also known to give out $100 tips (and $100 at the home office meetings).

Title: "The Bees was the bomb great place to work cool people and fun times"
Pros: Good people, easy work, friendly managers
Cons: You have to do the work
Advice to Management: Chill out

Title: "A job that satisfied my needs, that's all"
Pros: Allowed me to work with and make new friends while being able to make a quick buck when waiting on tables
Cons: Cons are that you are often screwed over.
Advice to Management: Don't try to maintain too many core competencies. It is difficult to maintain efficiency, value, and responsiveness all at once and placing the responsibilities on employee's is unnecessary.

Title: "Very unfair place of emloyment. They lie and will backstab without a blink"
Pros: Money....besides that, nothing. The regulars are nice and I did enjoy the staff I worked with.
Cons: They still from there employees. They change your schedule without telling anyone. They make up excuses and lies to turn employees on one another. Managment often calls you off from your shift minutes before it starts by a tex from other employees. You get ridiculed constantly for petty things such as the amount of ice that is in a glass or the smile on your face not being as geniune as it could when you have 100's of customers to serve.
Advice to Management: Get new managers that care about the store and employess

Title: "no quality of life when you almost always work the closing shift"
Pros: the food was actually good, the salads were quite tasty, but the steak is average at best. If only they were smart enough to switch to a more superior steak, such as black angus. they should do away with sirloins and go to ribeyes, t bone, and fillet minon.
Cons: supervisors were bad at best, unless you like working a thankless job, underpaid and hit on by a pervert, where you are belittled, lied to, and never ever thanked for doing a good job. if this sounds good, then good luck.
Advice to Management: get another job unless you like working long hours on your feet and don't expect to be promoted, because the current trend is to demote managers. I have seen area managers demoted to general managers and general managers demoted to kitchen managers most recently, hows that for job security.

Title: "Decent job, but couldn't have done it any longer than a couple years"
Pros: Good managers, fun and young co-workers
Cons: Not a lot of money, terrible customers

Title: "Good"
Pros:
Good night tips usually, depending on the location as serving goes
Opportunity to move up if the managers like you
$100 bonus for 100% secret shoppers!
Contests with bonuses
Cons:
abnormal amount of complaints and mistakes from the kitchen
Mixed bag of good and bad management
Very few servers and hosts did their weekly side work, I did mine and management would complain that I didn't get off the clock as fast as everyone else.
Advice to Management:
I appreciate that your taking steps to make sure the cooks in your restaurants are cooking the food properly. I used to get a lot of food complaints, it's always disheartening.
Managers should not cut peoples hours for not pushing surveys enough. Most of the people who are favored for getting the surveys are taking them home and doing them themselves.

Title: "Keep on Moving and Don't Stop to Apply Here"
Pros: The staff was decent most of the time.
Cons:
55-60 hrs a week
Horrible pay
Required to do more than anyone person could possibly manage to do in one day
Advice to Management: Seek managment experience somewhere else!

Title: "As thing s in the economy get bad managers get punished."
Pros: The other managers are great people.
Cons: Changes in upper management puts you in a you never know what to expect situation.

Title: "good money potential, flexible hrs"
Pros: hooked up with stafflinq.com- very easy to lose or pick up shifts; schedule gets txt to my phone as well as available shifts and important announcements. Flexible hours;busy restaurant so good money potential if you have a great section and if the hostess pulls her head out of her @$$$$.
Cons:
sections are unfair (at my store)
hostess/host should really have server experience so they know how it feels when they dont follow rotation, skip sections and quadruple seat people. Instead its mostly 15 yr old teeny boppers, batting their eyes at the line cooks and walking around with a clueless expression. Since we HAVE to tip out the host it would be nice if they were more proactive about cleaning off tables.
Advice to Management: Divide the restaurant into more equal sections. One section will have 6 booths while another has 2 two top tables and one four top. Which always leaves a few servers getting jipped because they have no booths! That makes the difference between a $20 night compared to a $60.

Title: "Treats lower level employees poorly, but the money is better than everywhere else"
Pros: The money is fairly good.
Cons: The culture is very political and clique-y
Advice to Management: Stop behaving like you're still in high school

Title: "Hard labor and low pay"
Pros: Met great people and worked with my friends through college. Fairly flexible work schedule.
Cons: Long hours, sometimes horrible tips. Managers could yell at you for no reason.

Title: "it was good sometimes and it sucked other times"
Pros: nice place to work meetnew people
Cons: they had thier favorites that would get to do what what ever they wanted to do
Advice to Management: treat evryone the same way if you let one employee smoke on the backdock let them all

Title: "I Miss Working Here..."
Pros:
-Great hours
-Amazing co-workers and management
-Good tips depending on shift and day of the week
-Food discount is okay...during training you get free meals!
-During daily shift line-ups you get the opportunity to sample a food and beverage (which is great with helping you learn the menu!)
Cons:
-Corporate..
-Force you to push surveys on the customers, most of which could care less.
-To strict with server scripting..they say that you are supposed to be yourself and bring out your personality, but then they make you recommend 2 alcoholic drinks, two appetizers, two entrees, and dessert.
-Corporate forces the kitchen to skimp on portions which angers guests, which in turn screws over the servers because in order to get them more of whatever was skimped we have to charge them extra (aka queso dip, spinach dip)

Title: "It was eye opening to say the least..."
Pros: Awesome people to work and to hang out with. They usually have good connections!! my time working there was uplifting and sort of trippy sometimes but it was really fun.
Cons: weird crowd sometimes. but good experience overall
Advice to Management: i liked management for the most part. had good relationships with some of the management team and felt it was easy to move up the ranks there

Title: "A lot of B.S."
Pros: I can't think of many.
Cons: Drama everywhere, co-workers act too busy yet the restaurant is empty
Advice to Management: The head manager needs to be removed, he can't do his job at all. He will make everyone absolutley mad, and then wonders why everyone is quitting.

Title: "Meh"
Pros: Decent hours during peak seasons.
Cons:
Poor management.
Kitchen always crashes.
Slow peaks expect 1-3 days a week and not even many hours those days.
Advice to Management: watch crew better

Title: "Over-worked, underpaid"
Pros: easy way to get your foot in the door of the restaraunt business
Cons: the hosts also work as the bussers, payed server salary with a small payout of servers' tips
Advice to Management: Hire bussers, pay normal pay rate to hosts

Title: "Depends on Management"
Pros:
If you are a closer you can make great money.
Great training program.
Cons: Depending on management they play favoritism by either who sucks up to management the most or who goes out with them after work. They overstaff like crazy so if you're not a favorite and you're usually cut first, you're lucky to get 2 tables. Then after being cut you have to do a certain amount of work delegated by the closers, which usually includes helping them run their food and rolling silverwear they use. They get more money for us doing their work which gets frustrating.
Advice to Management: Recognize hard workers, not just your favorites. When you cut people, make the closers help with back of the house work, otherwise your cut workers are stuck there forever cleaning up closers messes as well while they continue to make tips. Also, when being cut, management should distribute duties, not closers who benefit from the cut employees staying after getting paid less than $3 an hour to run their food or roll their silverwear. Also stop overstaffing--it's a waste of time to come into work and only get one table...have people scheduled "on call" and if you're busy call them in.

Title: "Server"
Pros:
Normally very busy so you can make a little bit of money
Managers are very good about working around your schedule
Cons:
Open late
Manager's get moved around to other locations too much
Side work is exhausting
2 of my managers were caught stealing from the restaurant
Advice to Management: Do some background checks on your managers

Title: "Chaos at Applebees"
Pros: Easy to get a job, growth potential
Cons: Chaos and disorganization describes the whole organization

Title: "Just ok."
Pros: Vacation time.is good. I've been able to earn 160 hours of vacation time. I work a typical 50-55 hour work week but when I take a week off I only lose 40 hours of PTO.
Cons: There is not a lot of support from higher ups when it comes to understanding daily tasks in the restaurant.

Title: "Standard Corporate Restaurant Job"
Pros: Fun atmosphere, great people, and never bored
Cons: Rude customers, understaffed, disliked my GM (the rest of my managers were okay though)
Advice to Management: Schedule more hours for the kitchen. Two people cannot possible run a kitchen for a $60,000 a week restaurant.

Title: "Bartending at Applebees"
Pros: You get to meet some great people
Cons: The management and the corporate life.
Advice to Management: Learn to lead and not to manage

Title: "applebees waitress"
Pros: corporate so not as many kinks as a smaller family run business may have.
Cons: the more you give the more they may take advantage. They work their managers very hard and they burn out quickley. The company rewards rude people by giving them free meals

Title: "Applebee's-Concord"
Pros: FLEXIBILITY!!!! Applebee's is very accomodating when it comes to your availibilty. If you have school, another job or something unexpected comes up such as a family emergency, they will work with you. You wont find another company more flexible with scheduling. They also have a program called Concord Cares that will help pay for unexpected expenses like a funeral or medical bills. Most of the time its $500.00. Also Concord cash. Its like money you earn for doing a good job and you can buy some pretty nice things off of their website. I myself have bought a dvd player, a Bath and Body Works gift card valued at $50.00 and a blow dryer and hot roller set.
Cons: Managers and employees alike seem to come and go as if the company is a revolving door. Aside from the couple of programs they have and the flexible scheduling, there's not much incentive for keeping your job. No raises for servers. Hosts pick and choose who they want to give tables to and they don't like to help clean off tables which they should do since the servers have to tip them out sometimes as much as $25.00 out of the servers tips. They need to pay the hosts an hourly wage so the servers can keep their money that they earned. Sometimes the managers get on power trips and treat the employees like slaves. And all black uniforms are ugly and depressing. Applebees is supposed to be known as a fun, laid back, family oriented casual dining place so we should be wearing colors and jeans. How professional do we need to look to serve people sandwiches and salads in a sports bar and restaraunt? We are going to our "fun job", not a FUNERAL!!!
Advice to Management: Colors people!!!! Seriously. Change the uniforms! Even guests say stuff about it all the time. Black is depressing, not fun. And give your servers that have been there and have been dedicated raises once in a while. $2.13 is not enough when we get 5% and 10% tips more often than you realize. Pay the hosts mimimum wage so we can keep our money too!!! Put yourselves in our shoes. BTW, we are there to serve, not deep clean the facility. Yes we need to keep it clean but sometimes it goes too far. I do not get paid to clean hair wads from the bathroom floor drains.

Title: "Great work environment, low pay, no salary raises"
Pros: My co-workers were really awesome, I really enjoyed working with them daily. When restaurant slows down we have time to talk and socialize, and they were all very helpful to another.
Cons: There are no wage increase, regardless of how long you've worked there. (Hosts) whether you get promoted to a server depends on the General Manager and they do play favorites.
Advice to Management: Wish the management would treat all employee equally.

Title: "An indoor circus"
Pros: Frankly, I can't think of anything.
Cons: I have never worked at any other place that had such a huge clique problem. At this restaurant there was an "in group" of people who had been working there longer than a year or two. This group included most of the managers. If you weren't one of them, you could not expect any sort of remotely polite interaction or fair treatment. Servers spend way too much time talking, joking around, and playing pranks on new employees. They then blame the cooks and hosts/hostesses when they don't receive tips. They asked me to seat certain people in their section, based on the attractiveness, race, age, or gender of those people. Some attempted to bribe me by giving me large shares of their tips if I would agree not to seat diners of certain races or ages in ther sections (I did not accept this). I have seen employees stand right in front of guests and complain about having to serve them, not even caring that the people are sitting right there and listening. Talking to management is useless as the majority of them are very close friends with the staff and gladly join in their antics.
Advice to Management: Advise restaurant managers to separate their personal friendships and romantic relationship interests from work. Educate your staff about giving all guests equal treatment regardless of race, gender, and appearance. Sorry for the cliche, but you can't judge books by their covers, and you never know what a guest is really going to be like.

Title: "Fun at one time, but bottom-line driven after IHOP purchase"
Pros: Good pay, good benefits, great people
Cons: Bottom-line driven, didn't care about the people
Advice to Management: Don't forget what made Applebee's a great place to work....caring about the people

Title: "Great for some quick cash on weekends, if you can get the hours"
Pros: Working on weekends can add up on cash through tips pretty quick, great training program. The general manager got relocated recently so things might have changed.
Cons: Management is unwilling to work with you on availability and more times then none you will get stuck on a snore shift and make 20 dollars for 5 hours of work. The head managers really do not care about all of their employees including a lot of the assistant managers(who get re-located if they get too friendly with wait staff). Favoritism, of coarse and a lot of drama between all staff as well
Advice to Management: At least pretend to care about your employees

Title: "Good place to work for a first job"
Pros: Decent hours, works with school times and after school activities, great people to work with
Cons: Low pay, long hours (12+ hour days) on holidays

Title: "If you deserve to be underpaid and undervalued as an employee this is the place to work"
Pros:
Great relationships - the people that I had worked with and met as a result are some of the finest individuals I have met.
Fun environment - there was never a dull moment.
Nice regular clientele, I made friendships that outlasted my employment there.
Cons:
Micro management defined - daily emails reminding managers to do the most basic of duties this was insulting and an incredible waste of time.
Unachievable bonus structure - says it all.
Ridiculous incentive contests
Advice to Management: Pay for true talent, give them direction and allow them to succeed.

Title: "Long hours pays my bills"
Pros: Hours with great people to work with.
Cons: Like everyone else has said, its the people that make the place.
Advice to Management: Spread out the work load more, and make sure it gets done. If you dont check the finished product how do you know if it is finished or not????

Title: "Great Company"
Pros:
we work 50 hours a week and are encouraged to make time for family. its ok if you leave at 5:00 every now and then for family.

allows you to run your restaurant like you own it.
Nice bonus program
Great Area Directors that treat you like a person, not a number.
we make our budgets and are held accountable, but are allowed to move money from one account to another.
Cons: As the General Manager you control of your store. its only a bad place to work if you allow it to be.
Advice to Management: was hired in at General Manager.

Title: "Resturant Manager"
Pros: Easy for causal dining for experience manager. Closed on major Holidays. Quality of life good. Stores are low volume sales. Good company for a inexperienced manager.
Cons: Coupon driven company. Quality of food is in relation to their menu price point. Difficult to maintain BOH staffing due to pay scale.

Title: "My experience at Applebees has been really enjoyable."
Pros: I work with great people.
Cons: Not enough hours during the two week period.
Advice to Management: Provide the same amount of hours.

Title: "applebees top10 worst jobs"
Pros: training was fun. Equipment was new and high quality. I liked my co workers, always something to do to keep busy.
Cons: never enough people scheduled for the high volume of orders The servers never never tipped out, Always the same people worked the hardest while the other people slacked off and didn't get any warnings.
Advice to Management: none

Title: "Associate Accessibility"
Pros: The food is free most nights. Transfering to a new location is not very difficult. Work hours are flexible.
Cons: Scheduling is poor, the management team does not show consideration for their associates. The overall manangement does not provide effective training for their associates that are new or seasoned.
Advice to Management: Provide better training and customer service skills to the staff. Hire individual that can and will represent the well in customer services.

Title: "Good college jb"
Pros: Employed me through college, great team, employees like family
Cons: A lot of wrk, pay is not consistent
Advice to Management: Keep it up

Title: "Ok Place to work if you don't take it too seriously"
Pros: Fun People To Work With, flexible hours, works with personal schedule.
Cons: Management is constantly changing, and there's definite favoritism. Ranking system is bogus.
Advice to Management: Chill a bit on the whole customer online feedback thing. Nobody really does those, you all should realize we're doing them ourselves. Make sure you're all on the same page.

Title: "Poor management"
Pros: The original management staff was great, but they slowly quit or were fired. It was easy to make friends with coworkers.
Cons: Management did not care about the workers and played favorites. Many customers were rude and difficult. Workers were lazy and didn't follow rules or had other people do their job while they slacked off. Management was unprofessional and didn't take workers somewhere private to talk about private matters, they did it in front of anyone.
Advice to Management: Hire more professional managers and don't play favorites. Hold everyone accountable for their actions.

Title: "It was a great experience butthe enviroment kind of like high school to me"
Pros: Good money, especially a bartender. You make good friends with th cooks :) only!!
Cons:
Left alone on the bar cleaning and closing the bar also during store hours after10pm the carside to go person goes home and so the bartender is in charger of carside to go as we as the bar and usually thats when people come in!!!! Closing at 1 am ans being there cleaning till 2 am
People who i worked with was like high school kids - i was their age but everyone in the store had sex with everyone!!!!!!! Disgusting! Poor management. Long hours and never knew when you were going to get cut/done with your shift

Title: "Applebee's"
Pros: Good Salary and good benefits
Cons: Long hours and high turnover

Title: "Quick paced work with neglectful management."
Pros: The clientele were often kind and the coworkers were as well. The work was simple enough and sometimes fun and upbeat.
Cons: Often people did not communicate and made many mistakes and caused much frustration. My particular Applebee's did not treat employees very well in addition.
Advice to Management: They need to communicate better and promote people who can handle quick thinking and pressure to their management positions as well as those who respect their employees.

Title: "not worth the headach,stress"
Pros: quick money, easy to get into, good for students
Cons: not very good benifits, not good for hours, training skills not good
Advice to Management: treat all eployees the same and step up in the company

Title: "good starting place"
Pros: get to understand industry and a proper place to learn the skills to run your own company if you decide to
Cons: a bit competitive and need to be a sycophant in order to get ahead or just anything to go your way.
Advice to Management: performance review and peer review must be utilized

Title: "A good example of where I don't belong"
Pros: Flexible hours and good tips.
Cons: Low base wage and work is very tiring.
Advice to Management: Be kinder to employees and make them feel welcome

Title: "Line Cook Living"
Pros: Its fast paced and can be challenging although its simple to perform necassary tasks. The people you work with are pretty awesome. There flexible with hours withouth the usual grudge that comes with needing off from other fast foods and restaurants.
Cons: Its very hot and greasy. The kitchen is quite small for 6 cooks. Its not very great pay for the work your doing. You dont get overtime ever.
Advice to Management: Keep doing what your doing and try to be a little more patient its not easy in that kitchen.

Title: "Flexibility is about all you get."
Pros: The best reasons for working at Applebee's are the flexibility of the work schedule, which allows me to go to school, work, and have a family life, and the generally fast-paced work environment is also, at least for me, another benefit. Many times while I'm working 14 hour days half the day will disappear without me realizing it because of all the new guests to serve, granted this only happens during the holiday season on weekends.
Cons: No included gratuity for larger parties, only making $2.13/hr, which is more of a Utah downfall, and dealing with difficult guests.
Advice to Management: Included gratuity for larger parties!

Title: "Applebees fun place to work with some exceptions"
Pros: Truely is a fun place to work. Pay is average compared to other restaurants. Would like to see more pay for the little people..ie cooks hosts servers bartendars. Has timely feedback as far as employee reviews as well as a really neat way to decide raises annually. You do a self evaluation and the managers get togethor and agree to a specific pay raise, 0-5% with hardly anyone ever getting the 5%. But still usually all get a raise annually. I do enjoy my general manager and our district gm and reginal gm are terrific to work with as long as you remember they are not your friends. Manager training was done well in about 10 weeks time for new employees.
Cons: Unless you know the right people, getting time off is not an easy event in the management area. 50-55 hours a week, sometimes 60. Applebees needs to utilize a better way to resolve conflicts of interest. Many of their managers are dealing ineffectively with there employees. Turn around is being worked on, but is still relatively high. I think most restaurants around here are dealing with that issue, as our city has many many restaurants to choose from. Uniforms are dull, but they are working on that as well. Wish they would leave the menu alone...they took garlic bread away which caused many a gripe from our customers.
Advice to Management: Hours worked does not equal competant work. A manager can get a lot done in 45 hours. When you ask for advice from a manager, really want that advice. Many a Area director or Gm really don't value employee feedback. Raises could be a bit better, as our starting wage isn't competitive with other manager salaries. See Darden industries salaries, 46- 49,000. which includes bonus...wow!

Title: "Good"
Pros: I think all the skills that are required to do the job in this company are known to mi so because of that I want to join this company.
Cons: Just doing so many work
Advice to Management: Encourage for new innovative ideas.

Title: "cook"
Pros: Good atmosphere, staff are nice,
Cons: hard work, lots of time on your feet.
Advice to Management: Need to be more strict against staff eating food that isn't theres

Title: "Not too bad"
Pros: The environment, the people, and most of the customers were a very pleasant experience.
Cons: Management needs a lot of work. The overall company is falling down on competition with other restaurants, so job prospects may fall over the next few years.

Title: "Applebees"
Pros: The food is great and i love the coctails
Cons: you have to serve customers all day

Title: "less than a year host at applebee's"
Pros: a very good pay and friendly environment
Cons: long hours and weekends shifts

Title: "A good first job!"
Pros:
Had some fun times
The only good thing was the people there.
I liked the employee discount
Sometimes I made good money
Cons:
The cheapest clientele
Hated singing that birthday song
Had to do janitorial work as a server (Not all of them do this thankfully)
Food is alright
Management didn't help out
Advice to Management:
Hire managers that actually help out the front of house staff.
Back of house staff was at times very difficult to work with.
Better pay for back of house.

Title: "Manager"
Pros: A twenty word minimum is required for me to say there are ZERO pros to work for Apple Gold Group.
Cons: Don't expect anything but the bare minimum of salary, bonus, insurance, or any other benefits. I worked for the brand for over 10 years and loved it. I managed the last 4yrs under Apple American Group, the largest of all Applebee's franchises. Moved to NC and Apple Gold was the only franchise. I was warned by multiple recruiters and even an old area director who quit and went to Red Robbin, but Apple Gold is by far the worst company I've ever worked for.
Advice to Management: Learn how to treat your employees. Respect your employees. Talk to your employees.

Title: "Jinnette Reyes"
Pros: is excellent brand culture as you teach
Cons: You pay for all the work

Title: "sorry"
Pros:
Applebee's Grill & Bar have a high standard in Foods and training for all sections, there's a lot of training materials and are being supported Internationally and implemented, very Challenging we have yearly Assessment for every branch that every one are excited and proud
we can travel all around the globe to open certain restaurants
Cons: After all the hard work and dedication & sacrifices there's no appreciations there's a lot of good employee that they just let it go and no proper action from the higher management to keep them, all the good & hardworking men& women, a constant changing in higher management. and no increment
Advice to Management: have a proper evaluation of employee and valued all hardworking staff have plan to keep all the right staff that really care and work as an owner

Title: "Very good work!"
Pros: Cool people! My coworkers were really nice and I enjoyed working with them.
Cons: Some customers were mean. People just want everything to be flawless every single time.
Advice to Management: Stay golden.

Title: "Horrible"
Pros:
Coworkers were amazing
Discount was 50% off
Cons: Less hours for hostesses, no money unless you serve

Title: "made a family there."
Pros: the people are fun to work with, the atmosphere is friendly
Cons: lack of hours, pay doesn't match the amount of work
Advice to Management: some times the "bosses"/ upper management comes in and tells us to do something via SPEC, line wise during a rush it doesn't reach the desired quality in the desired time.

Title: "I loved working here"
Pros: excellent team all way round
Cons: management sometimes with bad attitude

Title: "Hostess Applebee's"
Pros: good atmosphere but definitely depends highly on the management of the specific restaurant.
Cons: Did not work in a busy area so didn't get as many hours but that was not the company's fault.

Title: "Solid empoyer"
Pros: Good benefits, stock sharing for qualifed
Cons: Downsizing while attempting to create a positive culture
Advice to Management: When downsizing everyone afraid to take risk, lots of knee jerk decisions

Title: "See You Tomorrow, not anymore"
Pros: Good Pay for senior managers and up
Cons: Long hours, micro managed, programs forced down your throat, limited benifits to hourly employees.
Advice to Management: Treat employees the way you say you want to treat the customers

Title: "Good potential for advancement, Too much focus on bottom dollar."
Pros: Oppurtunities for advancement are easily attainable if your work your butt off. Most stores stay pretty busy. Your attitude and personality determines what you make Foh.
Cons: As a Foh worker I wouldnt recommend working at any location with less than 1mil net sales. Dont expect any raises Foh and Boh raises are few and far between.
Advice to Management: Scheduling guidelines are set in place for a reason. Follow them and you will have happier managers. Quit forcing mgrs to run at minimum Boh staff and you will have happier customers, calmer Foh staff, smoother rushes and a cleaner, more efficient store.

Title: "Server/ Kitchen"
Pros:
Staff linq
You meet amazing people from managers to co workers
Make good tips depending on what shift and what zone
Kitchen you make money but its so repetitve especially fry
Sometimes the managers let you eat dead food....food that they dont meed or was put in incorrectly
About every month there are new menu items and you get to taste test them
They are so flexible with your schedule just as long as you dont push it
Laid back atmosphere, some managers seem to actually care and they actually listen
Cons:
Even though the managers are great, some tend to overlook sidework being done
Host sometimes fall out of seating rotation which I dont understand how cause there is a chart up there...its common sense if u ask me
Some servers tend not to do side work
Please pray you have a good line, cause our broil was horrible....30 minute check times on pastas, steaks
Sometimes prep is horrible and we run out of important stuff on the weekend.
Forced surverys that really the servers probably do themselves

Title: "No extra pay for an excessive amount of hours"
Pros: Free food, good upper management
Cons: No down time, no free time, taking work home to get the job done
Advice to Management: Staff more people and reduce everyones hours to 40 a week

Title: "It's a job that is not desirable but still helps pay the bills."
Pros: The GM here is pretty cool.
Cons: Constantly having managers who don't know you're job trying to tell you what to do. Low pay and low hours. Always working on weekends.
Advice to Management: If you are going to lecture someone on their job, you should actually know how to do it first.

Title: "Need gas money?"
Pros: Awesome people! Very friendly &customers are pretty cool. Tips are okay.
Cons: Working your butt off for WAY below minimum wages. Managers are not always orginazed, depending nights, tips cn b vry bad & do not get many breaks. Tip money servers mk is split between host and bartenders.

Title: "Very nice!!"
Pros: Real neighborhood connections outside and inside the store. .
Cons: Nothing to worry about the negative side. . .

Title: "Great place to have your first job, a part-time or second job, or take in to the next level and apply for management."
Pros: Flexible hours and variable shifts. You determine what you can earn. You can learn a variety of positions and increase your rate of pay. There are employee discounts on meals.
Cons: Can be long shifts of constant movement, lifting, and standing.
Advice to Management: Directly supervise the training of newly hired employees. Turn over is 100% due to inadequate training and seasoned staff unwilling to help. They often perceive competition rather than an addition to the team.

Title: "Great"
Pros: This was a great company to work for there were no issues.
Cons: If I had to name on ething it would be that you have to be ready to work with customers every day.

Title: "Great support in local communities"
Pros: Advancement, opportunity to work in multiple locations
Cons: salary, constantly changing schedule makes work/life balance difficult

Title: "Don't do it unless you really have to..."
Pros: You meet new people all the time, you get half price food all day, and people are always willing to take our shifts if you need off last minute.
Cons: There are customers that treat you like the scum of the earth. Managers have favorites who are "career servers" and they can do as they please without consequences. And don't count on a good job getting noticed.
Advice to Management: You should learn to treat everyone as equals and not ignore the behavior of your employees.
